Ottawa,
May 13, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In view of the fact that our appropriation for the current fiscal year has been drastically reduced it will not be possible to allow more than $50.00 toward the transportation of children to and from the Norway House Residential School this year. You should so inform the Principal. The Department expects you to co-operate with him in arranging to have the children taken to and from the school by their parents without cost to the Department.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.
Norway House Indian Residential School

REV. R. T. CHAPIN, B.A.
PRINCIPAL

NORWAY HOUSE, MAN.
May 2nd 1940.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Dear Sir,

In presenting the accompanying application for admission of Mary Jane Albert into the School, seeing she is now 16 years of age, may I make the following explanation.

The parents now have two younger children in the School. The home is not a healthy home. They lost one child from T.B. this winter. The father is now himself in poor condition. And so the parents are anxious to get this girl in the school for a couple of years, both to get a bit of training and be cared for physically. The Doctor too is anxious to get her out of her home where she is so liable to infection. Before letting her into the School however he X-rayed her chest to make sure there was no disease.

I hope the Department will consider her case and allow her to have a couple of years in the School.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Norway House, Man:
2nd May 1940.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith the application for admission to the Norway House Indian Residential School of Mary Jane Albert, aged 16 years.

I also enclose a letter received from the Principal of the school, bearing on the application, seeing that the applicant is already 16 years of age.

After consideration of this application, and the Principal's letter, will you kindly advise me of the Department's decision. Personally, I would recommend that the admission of this girl be approved for at least two years.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.:
Ottawa,
May 21, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant enclosing application for the admission of Mary Jane Albert to the Norway House Indian Residential School.

Under existing regulations, which require the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very extenuating circumstances, the Department considers it inadvisable to commit to a residential school for the first time a child of 16 years of age. Under these circumstances favourable consideration cannot be given to admitting Mary Jane Albert to the Norway House School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.
Norway House Indian Residential School

REV. R. T. CHAPIN, B.A.
PRINCIPAL

Norway House, Man.
July 6, 1940

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of Feb 26th before me. I thank you for your letter and appreciate the situation as you explain it. The mentioned pupils are leaving the school this summer.

May I put before you our views concerning our children. Re. the boys, we feel that for the most part it is best for them to get out with their parents after 16 years of age. But there are always a few who wish to continue their school work and whose parents wish that they remain if possible. We feel that these boys benefit by the extra time and training in responsibility, for the school really needs three or four older boys to help with the more responsible work. This year there are four such boys now 16 years of age whose parents wish to continue another year in school.

As to the girls we feel that in this locality it is to their benefit to remain a year or two in school after 16. There are usually a few...
Openings in hospital work or domestic service for responsible girls. At 16 years the girls are hardly ready for such positions. If they go back to their reserves at 16 the likelihood is that their people will soon arrange a marriage for them. For this also we feel the girls are better prepared if they can have another year or two in the school. So we are glad when the parents so wish and the Dept. is willing to keep some of these girls on. We feel it is more beneficial for the girl to have this time even if a young applicant has to wait another year for her admission. This year some of the parents wish their girl home but some would like them to remain if possible. Two parents from Cross Lake I have not been able to see yet but would like permission for the girls to remain if they so wish.

The following then are the children for whom I would ask permission to remain another year:

Jacob Wm York
Robert Crate
Tommy Anderson
Lazarus Dee V

Lena Perch
Priscilla McKay
Christina Beandy
Matilda Moon

Yours truly,

P.T. Chapin

(I am writing this from Winnipeg and have not the children's numbers with me)
Ottawa, July 15, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, the Department approves the following pupils remaining in the Norway House Residential School for another year:

Jacob Wm. York, Lena Perch,
Robert Crate, Priscilla McKay,
Tommy Anderson, Christina Beardy,
Lazarus Bee, Matilda Moor.

If you wish them to remain after June 30, 1941, it will be necessary for you to make another application. It is presumed that the four pupils mentioned in my letter of February 26, last, are being discharged this year.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend R. T. Chapin, B. A.,

With reference to the first named, Elizabeth May Budd, I beg to say that this girl is the illegitimate daughter of Irene Budd, until a year ago, No; 655 Norway House Band, but now married to Jimmie Knott, No; 335 Island Lake Band. The above child however was adopted a year or two ago, by the uncle and aunt of the mother namely, Johnnie Budd, No; 567 Norway House Band, and his wife. With regard to the applications of Henry Chubb and Betsy Hart of Oxford House Band, it will be noted that these have been made out on foolscap, with the Physical Examination Certificate attached. The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.:
Sir,

With reference to pupils No; 0337, Rose Bradburn, and 0338, Norma Bradburn, of the Norway House Indian Residential School, I beg to advise that these girls are the daughters of Donald Bradburn, who was No: 608 Norway House Band, and who became Enfranchised with his family, as per Departmental letter No; 8123-19 of the 19th March 1940.

As the above two children are now enfranchised, they are of course no longer Indians, but the father would like them to continue their education at the Norway House Residential School for at least another year or two if the Department will permit them to do so.

The girls are now about 14 and 12 years of age; have been in the school since September 1938, and are now in grades 4 and 5. Both are bright students.

The father's request is that the girls might be permitted to remain as pupils of the school until they reach the age of 16, and I would recommend favourable consideration of his request by the Department.

The father, Donald Bradburn, I may say, is operating a trading store at Oxford House.

Will you kindly advise me what decision the Department arrives at in the above matter.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby,

Dear Sir:

A request has been received today from Mr. A. E. Caldwell, Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School, re accompanying the Treaty Party this year to God's Lake, Island Lake and Oxford House in the interests of recruiting pupils.

It is noted that Canadian Airway's quotation re treaty flights was based on a single passenger fare rate plus per pound rate for express carried. Mr. Caldwell states he would require to carry practically no baggage as he would live with the United Church Missionary at each location.

Will you kindly advise whether or not the Department would have any objection to Mr. Caldwell accompanying the Treaty Party as requested, providing he paid his own transportation - and accommodation were available in the aircraft used.

Yours very truly,

Chas. N. C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Children of Albert Richard
No. 448 Cross Lake Band.

During Treaty payments at Cross Lake this year I was approached by Mr. A. E. Caldwell, Principal of the Norway House United Church Indian Residential School who requested a ruling in connection with the above noted.

Mr. Caldwell gave me a statement signed by Albert and Sarah Richard - copy of which is attached - and explained he had received an application from these people to have their sons William and Walter who are now pupils in the Cross Lake Roman Catholic Indian Residential School admitted to the Norway House United Church Indian Residential School.

The Principal of the Norway House School refused to accept applications for admittance of these children until a ruling from the Department was received.

Richard Albert states he has always been a Protestant. He married a Roman Catholic woman but he informed me she changed Faith and was accepted into the United Church at Cross Lake in 1933.

In 1936 the oldest child, Katie, now aged 12, was admitted to the Norway House School.

In 1940, William, now aged 11, was baptised into the Roman Catholic Church and admitted to the Cross Lake School, January 27th of that year.

On October 3rd, 1940, Walter, now aged 8, was admitted to the Cross Lake School.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Canada.
The father now wishes to remove his two sons from the Cross Lake School and place them in the Norway House School.

Will you kindly advise what action should be taken in this connection.

Yours very truly,

C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Canada.
STATEMENT OF ALBERT RICHARD, TREATY INDIAN, CROSS LAKE BAND,
Taken This 11th Day of August, 1941.

I am, and always have been, Protestant, a member of the United Church of Canada. My wife was Catholic but was received into membership of the United Church of Canada in 1933. My wife and have six children, three being of school age. In August, 1938, I placed one child (my oldest) in the Norway House Residential School. In 1940, I placed two children in the Cross Lake Roman Catholic School, having been sent for by the Principal and requested so to do at the Catholic School.

It is the wish of myself and my wife that our children should be raised in the Protestant Faith and attend a Protestant school. I hereby voluntarily make the request that my children, at present in the Cross Lake Roman Catholic School, be transferred immediately to the Norway House Residential School.

No inducement has been offered and no influence brought to bear by anyone connected with the Norway House Residential School or with the United Church of Canada to require me to make this request.

Dated at Cross Lake Indian Reserve this 11th day of August 1941.

Norway House.
April 1st, 1901.

Dear Mr. Short,

There has been a council today and tonight Albert sent the Councillor in to order me to pull down that fence against the house (near Old Chief's). Of course I have refused to do that, and shall not do so unless I receive specific orders from yourself or some one else representing the Indian Department.

As you will be going into Winnipeg I wish you would fully explain matters to the Commissioner.

I send my returns herewith which I trust will be satisfactory.

I am, Yours sincerely,
(Sgd) E.F. Hardiman.
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose a copy of a letter addressed to Mr. ex-Agent Short by the Principal of the Norway House Boarding School, Berens River Agency, which explains itself, and as I fail to find trace of any agreement as to the site of the school or the amount of land reserved for school purposes between the Church, Indians, or the Department, I should be obliged to have some light thrown if possible on the subject. I may say that Mr. Short knows nothing of any agreement in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

Ottawa, July 9, 1910.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo, in which you ask for a copy of an agreement which was made between the Indians of Norway House and the Rev. John McDougall in reference to some extra land in connection with the Mission at that point.

In reply I beg to say that no agreement such as the one to which you refer is to be found on the school files and the Department is of opinion that none was forwarded.

Sir,

In accordance with instructions I beg to enclose a sketch showing site for a proposed new Boarding School at Norway House Indian Reserve.

I consulted both the Principal of the School and the Indian Agent and went over the ground with them separately and can assure you that this is the best site on the Reserve.

It is high and dry, well above the lake, can be easily drained, and is away from the main trail of the Reserve and public portions, at the same time being conveniently situated. The drain will probably have to be cut through rock but the distance to be blasted is short and of no great depth.

A dock with a good depth of water and a convenient place for storehouse can be cheaply built.

A sufficient area for playground will also be about the school while with the old grounds and the proposed extension all the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6270, file 581-9, part 1)
all the land required for garden or farming purposes is available.

I may say that land suitable for cultivation is yearly becoming a matter of more concern with the Indians. They may not use much of it at present but do not care to part with it, as they see that before long it will be of value to them. The amount of land on the reserve suitable for cultivation is very limited.

While the whole of the 40 acres promised is not good, a large proportion probably will be suitable for cultivation when cleared. At present except the proposed site it is covered with small spruce and scrub.

I counted 85 Indians present at the meeting when the matter was discussed and the land promised and only 5 voted against the proposal. These were men or those influenced by men whose so-called improvements were affected. I think only two are really touched.

A promise was given that where any improvements were taken the owner would be recompensed. It might possibly be necessary to take this small house near the...
near the school site to fully complete the grounds and remove what might be undesirable neighbors, but this is a matter for future consideration.

The proposed South limit of the extension east of the old grounds is moveable as it may infringe on the improvements of our Balfour an Indian which will consist only of some fences.

It was promised that his house and garden would remain undisturbed.

As the South limit is moved North the East limit will be moved East so as to include 40 acres. All the grounds, gardens, buildings etc. of the present School are included in the land promised.

I might say that the 85 Indians present at the meeting would contrast favorably in physique, dress and intelligence with an assembly of an equal number of white men taken from an average village, and were the finest body of Indians I have ever seen together.

The Chief William Craig is a very intelligent man, reads, writes and speaks English.
English and takes an active part in promoting the welfare of his people. Agent Calvert has a great deal of influence with them and they pay great attention to what he says. This is one of the few reserves where I have not heard anything said against the Agent especially by the young men.

The old school is in a bad condition. I went over it in company with Agent Calvertly on the 11th August and nearly three inches of water was then standing in the cellar. This has been caused by dampness. It looks as if it would be almost impossible to heat it. The partitions are open from the basement to the top of the building and is open at the eaves.

There is a continual draft between the walls and were a fire to start the whole thing would be in flames in a few minutes. As the windows in the sleeping dormitories are barred I do not see how the children could be saved. The danger is fresh as no less than 18 stories are in use in different parts of the building, which is necessary to have the windows barred as owing to the position of the building.
Care has to be taken to watch the inmates or patients.

In passing I may state that all the department buildings at this Agency are in a bad state. The plastering in the Agent's house is in a very bad state especially for a Government building. It is all cracked, a great deal is loose and large patches are off. The Hudson's Bay Co. people tell me it is a mistake to plaster buildings as with the dry cold, poor wind exposure, it always cracks and becomes loose in a few years, and that the only satisfactory way is to use lumber for walls and ceilings.

A storehouse is required as what was used as one is now the nurses quarters between the two tents used for hospital purposes. If the Department see fit to continue and build an hospital there would be sufficient room on the proposed new school site or on the old grounds. Tent Hospitals do not seem suitable for winter patients except consumptives.

The question of fuel at this point is also rapidly becoming a serious question. There is not a large amount on the Reserve and what...
and what there is will have to be concerned.

Fuel can now be got off Dominion Land,
but with the extension of the Reserve a
certain amount of this has been cut off,
and in the future will have to be brought
a considerable distance.

While not personally greatly in favour
of Boarding Schools if there is any possibility
of getting the children to attend Day Schools
or a School where they are not entirely
separated from the home, I may say that
a Boarding School seems to me the
only kind that is suitable for this particular
district. Even on the Reserve living as
the Indians do, scattered over the whole
Reserve on each side of the Lake it is
impossible to have many of them attend.
In summer boats are not always
available or if so the fishing interferes
also the chances of a heavy sea setting up
at any time prevents children from coming.
In winter they cannot come without being
accompanied by some older person.

This being a central point to which
many Indians from the outside, North and East
come during the summer a new complete
and up-to-date school seems to be a
necessity.

T Ferrier, the Superintendent of Methodist Missions, to be sufficient to settle the location on a site which, on examination, Mr. Ferrier could not entirely approve of. The views of Mr. Ferrier on this matter were stated by him in a letter to me dated August 15th 1913, and of which you have informed me a copy was sent to your Department by Mr. Ferrier.

It was not possible for Mr. Bunn and myself to attend to the business for which we made this lengthy trip and leave on the return run of the steamer from Warren's Landing to Selkirk, so we had about four days time for investigating the various matters in which we believed that our opinions would be quite acceptable to your Department and in the interests of the Public Service. The lower foot of excavation in the test holes showed a hard clay, that in my opinion, has a bearing capacity of two tons per square foot, which is more than ample for the purpose of this building. The lower clay was found to be of the same nature in all of the holes.

In answer to my inquiry as to the nature of the site for the Methodist Boarding School at Norway House, I am pleased to inform you that the soil is suitable for the purpose intended.

House, I was informed in a letter dated November 8th 1912 that the site "is described as high and dry". I now know that such description cannot be relied upon for anything but the ground surface and I have to regret that we did not provide in the specifications for putting weeping drains at the footings of exterior walls for such drains are surely a requisite to all buildings of a permanent character in this district where the basements are to be adapted for usage. More will be said in this connection when describing the conditions found at the Indian Agents dwelling.

Under the assumption that the Boarding School would be erected on the site selected by Mr. Lousley we were informed that water could be obtained from the Lake, some seventy yards from the building, and we were further informed that a drainage outlet could be had within a comparatively short distance from the building. With the new location neither of these conditions exist, as will be seen by reference to the plan here-with. I feel free to state that we would make a great mistake if the water supply for our building were obtained from the source named in the specifications, for from my observations of the conditions prevailing on September 8th, I can inform you, that the water from that source would be unsuitable for drinking purposes especially at times of low water in the Lake.

The new location of the Boarding School, and other conditions affecting the district require that a well be sunk for procuring a supply of good water and that a system of drainage be provided of much greater extent than we had been advised would suit the conditions of the site that had been abandoned. I requested Mr. Jno. Little, who is a very practical man, in charge of the construction of the buildings for which Messrs. Snyder Bros. have the contracts, to make investigations in regard to the possibilities of obtaining water by means of sinking a well. When Little tells me of his findings I may, at some future time, suggest to you a method of supplying water not only to the boarding School, but to the Hospital and possibly other buildings.

Inspector Bunn, will surely report to you of our examination of the dwelling occupied by Agent Stewart but as I do not know what Mr. Bunn may say, I would inform you that the condition of the dwelling is deplorable and that in my opinion the root of the trouble lies in the Basement and foundation walls, which on account of bad drainage conditions have been very much damaged by the action of frost through past winters. Owing to the
Granite rock underlying this district, surface water gathers in places which may not be determined from superficial observation, and unless such accumulations be carried away by drainage, the water will remain and in the cold periods when frost extends fully five feet below the ground surface, a foundation, especially if it is of masonry construction will suffer much damage.

The Boarding School and Hospital Buildings at Norway House will be, without doubt, the most important erections within a radius of several hundreds of miles and inasmuch as the district is more primeval and the requirements of drainage have not been investigated or properly recorded by others before us we had either to anticipate contingencies that might have proven to be non-existent, or to act as we have on the meagre information given to us when drawing up the specifications. On account of what was discovered at the dwelling of the Indian Agent, I directed that weeping drains be put to the foundations of both the Boarding School and Hospital and I hope that the drainage pipes may be delivered at the site so that they may be put in place before the Contractors stop their operations for this season.

On the plan herewith we have indicated a location for a main drain from the Boarding School to the Nelson River or its enlargement named Little Playgreen Lake, also a branch from this drain to connect to the Hospital Building. Sir,

I have to acknowledge your letter Number 168918/1,
dated 17th October, 1913, in reply I beg to offer the following
as a report of the work done in connection with the examination
and selection of the site for the proposed New Boarding School
Building at Norway House. I received from the Department a
blue print plan showing the area within which the proposed site
would have to be chosen and which was carefully consulted by
Mr. Matthews and myself when we were doing this work.

I left Winnipeg for Selkirk at 1.30 P.M. on the 4th September. Mr. Matthews took the same car, we arrived in Selkirk in
due course to take steamer for Warren's Landing, the steamer
arrived at that point at 8.45 A.M. on the 5th, from this point
we proceeded to Norway House by Gasoline Launch and arrived
there at 4.20 P.M. the same day.

Without any delay and the weather conditions being favorable, Mr. Matthews, Mr. Lousley and myself took up the work of
making a selection of a suitable site. Mr. Matthews was the directing spirit in doing this, and as he was an entire stranger on the
ground, he desired to see all the possible available sites first.

SELECTION OF SITE.

The first site looked over was that chosen at some previous time and on which an excavation and some other work
had been done under the charge of Mr. Lousley, Mr. Matthews and the party I have mentioned, examined the site thoroughly. Then other grounds were looked over, the site of the old school was visited, this was examined and enquiries made with reference to it. Then a site located, in what was used as a potato field and vegetable garden was examined, this site at once created a favorable impression on Mr. Matthews and myself, and so far as we could see presented natural conditions that easily made it a very desirable location on which to erect a New School Building. However, it was decided that we would take more time to arrive at a decision, so on the following day (the 7th) Mr. Matthews and I went over all the grounds again, we visited all the sites that were thought to be possibilities, and we were more fully convinced that our opinion about the site in the Potato field was right, it was decided to test the new location in the Potato field; the tests made were performed under the direction of Mr. Matthews. Test pits were sunk to prove the grounds, the result was very satisfactory, these tests and results definitely convinced us it would be wise to abandon the site on which work had been done, as from the examinations we had been making, we were fully satisfied that we had located a much better one. The selection of the new site on which the New School Building will be located at Norway House, opens up new problems as to water supply, drainage and sewerage, proper consideration was given to these in making the selection, and in this connection I beg to offer the following.

WATER SUPPLY.

A supply of water from the lake is one that is open to very serious objections, looking to sanitary conditions, the Lake as a source of water supply is too doubtful as to the quality of the water. At certain seasons and under certain conditions the Lake is not a safe source. On the new site the water should be from a well, this source of water
supply would be safest and best. The Contractor has obtained a liberal quantity of water and of good quality, by sinking to a depth of 11 to 12 feet.

DRAINAGE AND SEWERAGE.

The question of drainage is one that I think will be evidently readily and satisfactorily adjusted, the Contractor has proved this. He opened up a surface drain to carry off any surface water that might accumulate and interfere with his foundation excavation operations, this resulted in a satisfactory manner. This drain can be continued and sunk to a proper depth and extended to the Lake very easily, as there is no apparent interruption by rock. With these conditions for drainage, a dry basement and grounds about the building are apparently assured.

All of which is respectfully submitted,

I have the honor to be,

Dear Sir,

I have your letter No168918-1A before me and the sketch you sent of Hope Island which we have applied for in the interests of the agricultural interests of this school. I have marked the location of the improvements of Chas. Sanders the small peninsula has on it all the improvements that he has made. He has a house, a small stable and a warden. He has three or four head of cattle and I believe he is selling all but one. These cattle range through the island. We would not wish to deprive him of any of his property nor the necessary privileges he has had for pasture nor fuel. When asking for the island it was in my mind to let him have the point where he lives, free range for his cattle and the free chance to get his wood same as before. However I see a possible difficulty that may arise in the future.

There is a block of good land which has been partly cleared some four years ago where some wood was taken off near his peninsula. I have marked it as nearly as I can with pencil. I would suggest that No 27.6 and no 11.1 besides his point be left out of the rest for the present. If he wishes to use that, he will have all and more than he will use of good land and fire wood. If he should wish to move at any time as he has been talking to the south of Lake Winnipeg we could buy his improvements and have the complete Island. If our developments should encourage him to do likewise he could have a good chance.

I have marked as nearly as I can the spots of the Island that has soil that can be made arable; the rest is rock and muskeg as well as
some that is marked off. We have a shack and stable which I have marked and have gone already to some expense cutting bushes besides taking special care in cutting wood with the view of getting it ready for cultivation.

The school is situated on the Indian Reservation and the Indians refuse to give any more land. We only have forty acres and some of that is rock. We are badly in need of more land and this is the only promising prospect we have. If you could arrange for us to have the rest of the island & leaving the portion I have indicated near where Sanders lives we would proceed with our improvements and make the best use we could of it.

You will understand by this letter that we wish it to be made definite that it is to be for the use of the Boarding School. The Indians do not need it as they have much more than they make use of. We are anxious that it be made clear as we do not want to go to the expense of improvements until we are assured that we will be given the use of it.

It would be a great benefit to this North country if a good farm could be developed and I can imagine that the Government would be appreciative and interested in such an attempt. This year we have corn for table use, a good many tomatoes ripening on the vines and almost every variety of garden produce. We had oats ripen by Aug. 20. We are only able to raise a little compared with what we need. In three years we have increased our cattle from five to twenty-four. Our hogs from none at that time to twenty-four, sixteen of these are large ones. We are having more sows to farrow soon. We had one team now two and expect to get another. We have made the old small log barns answer for all this stock, we have cleared thirty acres from bush and have some broken and the rest in pasture so you see we are sincere in what we ask for and are careful not to put the department to great expense in our efforts at developments. I think also that you will
feel that we are not trying to do any injustice to Mr. Sanders and we would be the first to rejoice at any attempt he might make to work up a little farm. I shall do anything to advise or assist him should he attempt it.

I hope this letter is clear and covers the points you wish to know. I hope that the Department of Indian Affairs will be able to take over this island and that tall but no 27.6 and 11.1 and the peninsula where Sanders improvements are will be assigned for the use of this School.

Yours very respectfully

[Signature]

P.S. I have endeavoured to find out how much good soil there is on the island and I have indicated as nearly as I can.

There is land just outside of our fence belonging to the Indians covered with bush, mostly bushes which for their good and ours for pasture needed, should be cleared. Our boys could easily do it if the Indians would be agreeable but I do not wish to suggest it to them as they think we want to take advantage of them about the land. As soon as it is advisable they ought to be approached with the proposition of cutting their school wood on this place and allow the boys to clear and pile the brush. This is only a suggestion that would require the careful attention of your officials.

We have been looking for information as to whether any action has been taken by the Department towards securing Hope Island for the use of the school for agricultural purposes. We have one side of it cleared and will be ready to burn the brush this spring. It should be ready where the first cutting was done for the plough as soon as it is burned over.

Geo. F. Denyes,

Sir,

In February last Mr. James Blackford, Principal of Norway House Boarding School, wrote the Crown Timber Agent in Winnipeg, asking for a free permit for a number of years, and a first option thereafter, to cut hay for the School on two islands some eight miles from the settlement. These islands were not being used for any purpose, were covered with willows, and useless for hay or apparently any other purpose in their present condition. Mr. Blackford offered to clear off the brush so that hay could be secured. The work this would entail would be worth the hay secured for some years.

This application was referred to the Controller of the Timber and Grazing Department, and his request denied. Mr. Blackford handed this correspondence to me some time ago, but since the refusal appeared to be absolute, except under the regular permits, I took no action. Since, however, I find that consideration is being given to an application on behalf of the Cross Lake Boarding School for the reservation of certain hay meadows for the use of the School, I think the same consideration should be given to the Application of the Norway House School.

I will endeavor to secure a sketch of the islands in question, showing their location, approximate area, and an estimate of the average annual yield if cleared, and a definite application to have these islands reserved for the use of the Boarding School for hay purposes.

Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith an agreement entered into by the Norway House Indians, The Norway House Boarding School, and myself, with regard to an exchange to be made between the said Indians and said School, and which exchange I consider would be to the interest of both Band and School.

When I met Mr. Russel Ferrier, Supt. of Indian Education, in Winnipeg last summer, he informed me that I was authorized to make an agreement along these lines with the Indians, and that the Principal of the School had been authorized to act on behalf of the School.

Almost every Indian present at the meeting was in favor of the agreement. Some wanted more land for the roadway at the north side, in fact wanted a roadway through the School property, but this would have been a continual source of trouble.

As to the agreement, I consider the Indians are getting rather the better of it, but the exchange would put all School buildings and property within the School fence, and in this way place these properties more directly under the eye and control of the Principal, and obviate all difficulties with the Indians.

As regards the roadway to the north of the property, it has been necessary each winter to open a road through the School property by taking down the fences. The making of this no longer necessary, will compensate for the small amount of land given up.

The exchange at the front of the property will give a little more ground in the front yard, and place the boundary fence a little farther from the building. It is now much too close. It will also give the Indians an addition to their recreation ground, which is too small. The corner given up by the School is garden ground, but juts out into the football ground where the young men play, and the ball is constantly being kicked over this fence, and the garden and fence are damaged considerably every season.

I may say that the map which I have of the School property includes the cemetery and the ground to the west of it, but this appears to be incorrect. I will endeavor, later, to have a fairly correct map drawn of the property, as proposed by this agreement.

While this Agreement does not follow the regular form, it is really not a Surrender, and I trust this will prove satisfactory, and that it will be accepted by the Department, I would recommend acceptance, since I consider it will benefit all parties concerned.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

The principal of the Norway House Boarding School has cut and cleared so that it can be well burned, about 40 or 45 acres of land on Hope Island. This was secured for the use of the Boarding School. He is now busy breaking and stumping the same, having purchased a stumping machine for this purpose. The entire cost will be in the neighborhood of $1,000.00. He has also cleared about 20 acres of willow land by the shore of the island and sown the same with grass seed. He has an excellent crop of grass on it this year which will save the purchase of hay at Selkirk and having it shipped in. There are about 50 acres more of the willow brush land. This could be worked into the same condition for hay purposes.

Would the Department bear the expense of having this willow land cleared? If your agent were authorized to do this he could furnish employment for some of the Indians. I have discussed it with Mr. Gordon and he thinks it a fair proposition. He assured me he would be agreeable to the same providing the Department would authorize it done. I would be pleased if the Department would take this matter up with Mr. Gordon. I would like to point out that there is no better time in the year to do this work than during the months of August and September as land cleared at that season is seldom followed by any undergrowth.

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

I have a Balance on hand for Votes 5 and 11, Treaty expenses of $156.47, and for Vote 7, Schools, General expenses, $175.20, with no expenses from either this month. The Balance on hand for clearing land for Norway House Boarding School is $1.00.

I have also paid out for labor on the new waterline, and repairs to sewer, and cleansing septic tank for Norway House Boarding School, the sum of $354.20. My authority for this expenditure is somewhat vague, Department letter No. 123-5-5 of Aug. 3rd, stated that the Winnipeg office had been given authority to have this work done. Inspector Bunn shipped the necessary material. I wired him, Aug. 29th, "If we to put in pipe line by day labor, send ten spades and ten shovels, and Nine Hundred Dollars, also two hundred feet three eighths; pump rod." Inspector Bunn sent forward the spades, shovels and rod, but to date I have received no funds. As it was necessary to have this work completed before freeze up I proceeded at once with the work. As to sewer and septic tank, this was authorized in Dept. letter No. 123-5-5 of Aug. 13th. I have made no distinction in this work, as the same gang of men did both jobs. I mentioned the necessity of funds to cover this expenditure in my letter to the Department, of Sept. 3rd. I find the labor for the waterline, sewer, septic tank, and crib for intake, will cost approximately $1200. Unless the $900. asked for reaches me by the next mail, I will be placed in an awkward position as I will have no funds for the purchase of dog fish, or to pay for anything required, as the amount paid for this work will absorb the whole balance and we will receive no further mail until December.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of the 11th No. 123-5-9 re mission property at Norway House:

When I visited Norway House on July 24th I received a letter from Mr. R. Bayr requesting to lease sufficient ground to build a store. I discussed the matter with your agent, Mr. Gordon and gave him to understand that I was not in sympathy with any such policy. I pointed out to Mr. Bayr that the Methodist Church did not hold the deed of the land and that we had it for educational and missionary purposes. However, he handed me his request in writing and I promised to reply to the same. Courtesy at least demanded this. I feel sure the Mission Board of our Church would never consent to leasing a portion of this property without first turning it over to the Indian Department. The land in question is a good piece of garden land, well cleared and should be cultivated from year to year. It has been so used through the past years since it has been brought under a state of cultivation. It is a question whether the missionary requires this much land as there is now sufficient under cultivation to allow them to grow a very substantial garden.

If any change is made it should be given over to the boarding School for garden purposes as land is very much needed in connection with the management of the school for this purpose. So much so that we are spending considerable money and labor on Hope Island which is four miles away. If this arrangement would be agreeable to the Department I would bring it before the next meeting of the Board of Missions in October.

Yours respectfully,

T. Ferrier

Dear Mr Goodman:

Further to our conversation re the Principal's Residence of this school. We are proposing to rent this furnished residence to the three Day School Teachers for a term of ten months at a rental of Thirty dollars per month. This revenue we are devoting to pay insurance on the dwelling and the furnishings and also to pay for the expense in keeping it in good repair. The west side of the building was badly scorched when the school was burned, the wall will have to be scraped before repainting.

In reference to the Engineer's residence which is also Residential School property, we propose to lease this residence on a yearly basis until the time it will be required as a residence for a member of the staff of the new school. This residence is unfurnished, a rental of Twenty dollars per month is fair & just. I understand that you would like the newly appointed engineer to live in this residence, will you acquaint him with the terms.

May I explain the history of this building and its relationship to this school. Mr Stevenson the present occupant of the residence was formerly the engineer of the Residential School, later he was appointed in a dual capacity as Engineer for the Agency and the school, his duties in connection with the school in this later arrangement were to keep our machinery in repair and good working order. I may add here that we only called him in when unable to do the work ourselves, his time was so fully taken up with the hospital, agency and saw-mill that we were reluctant to call him away from his duties there. For these services of the Engineer we provided a residence and also paid one hundred and ten dollars ($110.00) per month for water, light, and part to the Engineer's salary.

Sir,

I am forwarding to you a sketch prepared by J. McLean D.C.S., in August 1910.

This sketch shows the site upon which the buildings in connection with this Agency are situated. The land is far too small for the number of buildings situated thereon. We have on this site, the hospital, Agency office, Agency residence, stable, dog kennels, warehouse, and ice house. The new stable for the horses, I have erected opposite the Agency site, down near the Lake shore, at the point marked X on the plan. You will see by this that our buildings are crowded too closely together.

On the west side of the Agency there is a piece of land owned by Councillor Charles Paul. This land is not a part of the Reserve. He is willing to dispose of his house and land to the Department for the sum of Three Hundred Dollars. The house is within fifty feet of the hospital. It is not desirable to have Indians residing so close to the hospital. If the Department sees fit to take this land over and add it to the Agency site, it will be a good location for the Doctor's residence some time in the future.

On the east side of the Agency there are two lots which have been occupied by William Sinclair and John Bull, these two men vacated this property some years ago. They have assured me that they are willing for the Department to take over their lots. William Sinclair has a close pole fence around his lot, he is willing to dispose of...
Sir,

this improvement to the Department for the sum of Fifty Dollars. I called a Council Meeting on Monday the 22nd of May, to ask the Band to surrender these two lots to the Department to be used by the Department of Agency purposes. I pointed out how closely crowded together our buildings were on the present site, and that I wished to remove the stables, ice-house, and warehouse to the land which I was asking for. Although the land asked for has not been used for years and there is no prospect of it being used in the near future, unless the Department should take it over, yet the Council refused to grant these two lots to the Department for Agency purposes. The reason for this refusal may be traced back to the time when forty acres was surrendered for school purposes. The people as a band seem to regret the surrendering of this Forty acres, and have repeatedly said that they would not surrender any more land for any purpose. So in view of this I would respectfully suggest to you that you secure these lots by expropriation, and compensate William Sinclair to the extent of Fifty Dollars for his improvements.

A still better thing to do, would be to expropriate the balance of the Reserve Land on Rossville Mission Point. This would mean that the whole point would be used for School, Agency, and Mission purposes.
Sir,

If this available land was secured I could put the public playground in better shape, and reserve these two lots for this purpose. If you see fit to expropriate the whole point, we shall be better able to make model grounds of our location. At the present time both the school and the Agency are pestered with dogs and cattle, and when the fly season comes this point is the rendezvous for all the Reserve cattle.

To expropriate this point I would suggest putting the fence at a point in the Bay marked "A" on the plan, to the south limit of the school land, this would mean that six men would have to be compensated for their houses, and I would suggest that Three Hundred Dollars for each one is ample compensation, with the exception of Alex Neckaway, who has built a new house which I would value at Five Hundred Dollars. The names of the other men are:

Thomas Balfour, Elijah Houle, Sandy Crafty Baptiste Seulier, and Philip Hart. The only other Indian residing on the Mission Point is Councilor Chas. Paul, whose land is not included in the Reserve. The purchase of this land, I have already suggested in this letter.

The total cost to the Department for the expropriation and purchase of the remaining land on this point would be only Two Thousand, Three Hundred Dollars. Then this point would be for the exclusive use of the Boarding School, Day school, Agency and
Sir,

Mission purposes, then we could organize some concerted effort to beautify this point. I would still reserve suitable site for the Treaty payments and put this site in good shape, also I would set apart a piece of land as public playgrounds and also put it in good shape.

There is, on the Mission Point, a small piece of land owned by the Hudson Bay Company, this piece of land is only used by them during Treaty payments.

I trust you will see your way to take up this suggestion and carry it out. I will take up the matter with Inspector Bunn, and he will no doubt, discuss the question with you.

crowded with people; half day classes, not more than about three hours daily in classes, is the vogue here, and the children are supposed to be outside in the fresh air as much as possible. Some swings, slides, etc., have been provided for their amusement. A certain amount of physical drill is given. The children admitted to schools are selected, and those having Tubercular tendencies are eliminated. There should be much less danger of T.B. infection in the school than in many of the reserve homes. Yet I doubt if the graduates are superior physically to the children who have grown up on the reserves.

From the economic standpoint, I would say, that so far as this section of the west is concerned, the school training is a failure. Our girls and boys have not learned any relationship between their earning power and those things (as to value) which they require, to live. Much of the school work is mechanical, and on a large scale, and they have not the initiative nor understanding to fit themselves into a smaller scale, and to hand work. Farming and stock-raising are of little use at Norway House, as we have very little arable land, and, in most season, little native hay. Gardening is valuable, and will become increasingly so. The ability to drive a horse, and to care for him properly, will have a value for a limited number. Cross Lake has more land and hay, and farm training will have a value to the boys of that reserve. The majority must trap, hunt, fish, paddle a canoe and carry on portages. They must build and live in winter camps, with very little social life for the winter, and without electric lighting, running water and steam heating, such as they have been accustomed to in the school. They must learn to live on a diet much less varied than that supplied in the school; consisting largely of fish, meat, berries and vegetables. They must not be too proud to see the advantages of the rabbit robe for bedding, and moose or deer skin for outer clothing.

I have always insisted that the education received by the boys in the schools should so develop their intelligence that they should, in a couple of years, be our best trappers, fishermen, trippers and freighters. This does not work out in practice. Doing the work as they grew up appears to be the best apprenticeship. I am of the opinion that I was on the right track some years ago when I asked for and received permission, in conjunction with the school principals, to have the older boys take their vacation in the trapping season, when they could go out and learn how to make the sets and care for the traps and the furs. This plan, however, did not fit into school programmes very well. May I ask that authority be again given to make such arrangements for vacations, and that an effort be made to place the boys with men who are themselves good trappers, and who would be willing to teach the boys how the work should be done. This might be done in individual cases where it would be likely to prove beneficial, and might be applied for the last two or three years of school. Also may I suggest that opportunity be given that assistance in the form of traps and outfit for a part of the first winter be given to graduating boys recommended jointly by the Agent and School Principal. This, of course, on condition that the boy get out and actually trap.
Until we are prepared to ration a large proportion of our Indians in this section, I consider we are making a mistake in insisting on the building of homes on the reserves as permanent homes, or on the cultivation of large gardens. The Indian trapper, who has a good home on the reserve, is very loth to leave it for the winter. If he lives on the reserve and journeys out to his traps, his visits are likely to be few, consequently he has dead traps and but little return. If he leaves his family at home, and goes out to camp himself, he will be likely to spend too much time visiting his home. His family will also cost very much more for support, as they will be dependent on store goods. For this reason I am not greatly in favor of assistance to the graduates in the form of house material, at least at the present time. It may appear to be a retrograde movement, so far as civilization is concerned, but self-support and the consequent self esteem I consider is much more important.

The decrease in grants from both the Department and the Mission Board for the coming year will make the financing of this school increasingly difficult. It is hard to say where cuts in costs can be made without disrupting the organization of the farmgardens, stock, etc., built up by years of effort and expense; or by reducing the staff, either of which would reduce the value of the school training. No increase in pupils, without a corresponding increase in accommodation, should be made. A re-organization from top to bottom might be effective in reducing costs, and if done carefully, need not diminish the value of the work of the institution.

Yours obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Wm. Gordon,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa.

August 24th 1943.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have been expecting to hear through the Agency about the appropriation granted on our 1943 estimates, but to date no information has been received. I am anxious to hear before the end of navigation, which, by the way, may be considerably earlier this year on account of shortage of wood put up on Lake Winnipeg for fuel for the passenger and freight boat.

Unless I can find some means of providing more stabling accommodation for our stock here at Norway House, it is almost a necessity that I dispose of at least some of the stock before winter sets in. I have been keeping some of the stock at the farm at Hope Island during the winter, necessitating the extra employment of a family there. In the present necessity for economy, I find that keeping this extra help will not be possible, even if it were not for the fact that the stable buildings at Hope Island, which are log, are so deteriorated that they are not suitable for winter care of stock. It would be very regrettable to have to dispose of the stock. When I came here two years ago there were only 7 head of milk cattle here, and the Principal had determined to go out of cattle altogether, as being too much expense. I saw some opportunity of overcoming this by undertaking the supply of milk and meat to the hospital. Since that time I have increased our stock so that I have now some nine or ten head of cattle to kill each fall, and plenty of milk for the hospital and the school. Just at present my stock stands as follows:

- 40 head cattle, of all ages.
- 23 Pigs, including brood sows and boar.
- 27 Goats, 12 milking.
- 5 Horses.

My plan is to winter all this stock (some 9 head of cattle and 20 pigs will be butchered at freeze-up) here at the school, eliminating Hope Island expense. I will require additional space for about ten head of cattle and the goats. Until such time as we can get either a new barn or a proper addition to the old one, lean-to buildings could be used. These could be built with lumber sawed from logs obtained locally, with the addition of shingles. The cost of getting the logs and the building would be approximately $500.00.

The cattle are a really fine herd, whether it would be better to go to the expense of adequately stabling them cannot be doubted.

It would be almost impossible to build up such a herd again under present conditions. Further, the expense of shipping cattle in the fall to supply the Hospital and the school with meat would be almost prohibitive. However, in the present financial situation, where the school is actually operating, or trying to operate, on a 30% increase cost of operation (figuring supplies and wages) with a revenue of 25% less than pre-war, is manifestly impossible, without the most rigid economy. Even with this economy, a deficit is bound to accumulate.

To complicate matters, the hay supply is most inadequate this year. The water is very high and has covered most of our hay grounds, which are located along the banks of the river and lakes. Where I should have normally at least 100 tons of hay cut up, I will be fortunate this year to get 50. This has had to be cut mainly on islands in Playgreen Lake and has to be hauled in some cases 20 miles. Formerly, during seasons of high water, the Indians were accustomed to cut the hay in the water, spreading it out to dry. This was not uncommon. Under present conditions however, with so much work being available in the harvest fields (over 100 men have left this reserve alone for the harvest) it is impossible to get men to cut hay. However, I am fortunate in having a good crop of oats which will be cut green and stacked. In this way, I may be able to manage, with careful feeding, through the winter. The stabling room, however, is most necessary.

We have a really fine herd of goats. They have been a distinct liability thus far. I could make some revenue selling the goats milk to the hospital, but the Doctor expects to get the goats milk at the same price as cows milk (until recently we were supplying cows milk to the Hospital at 5¢ per quart, this has now been increased to 10¢). Goats milk sells normally at about 35¢ per quart, and I would rather use it at the school than sell it at such low cost.

We have been unfortunate in our kid production during the last two years. This year, out of 15 kids, only 3 are nannies. The Billys are useless, of course, except for the small supply of goat meat which they provide. It is impossible to account for this adverse production of kids. I am changing the Billy this year. I have even suggested to Dr. Corrigan that there might be a chance to get some real results with his Vitamins in our goat herd........ but he does not seem to take kindly to the idea.

Our pigs are a real asset. I have a very fine type of Yorkshire and they have done remarkably well considering the very meagre and primitive accommodation we have for them. I wish we could have even a little of the fine accommodation and housing some other schools have.

I wish to make a note of the labour and staff problems. As you know, I received material to erect new outside class-rooms, we to supply all the material and labour that could be obtained here. Owing to the shortage of labour (for logging, hauling and building) I have been as yet unable to build this building. In fact, were the labour available, finances would not permit at present of the expenditure entailed. I have the material supplied stored in the warehouse where it will not deteriorate, and this work will be proceeded with as soon as opportunity affords. In the meantime, I am using the old outside class-room for the senior pupils.
I have also gone into egg and poultry production, which had not been introduced here. I have had some 40 chickens for over a year, and this year I purchased 200 day old chicks, out of which 170 have matured. Some of these will provide poultry for the hospital, but I will have about 150 in egg production during the winter. It was necessary to build a chicken house, which is partially complete, and needs to be lined and insulated for the winter.

This gives an outline of our live stock situation. There can be no doubt that our stock has contributed very greatly to the economical operation of the school. I do not know what we would have done during these difficult times had we not built up our live stock during the past two years. I feel that more land, (if it were obtainable within convenient reach of the school) and adequate stabling, is necessary to the continued better operation. What can be done under the present circumstances I do not know, but I am putting the situation before you.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

I don't know whether Mr. Lazenby has taken up with the Department the matter of the construction of a barge to haul wood and hay. I have discussed it with him and he agrees to the necessity. The old barge is useless. I tried to use it this summer in the hauling of wood, but the hull is so rotten that it cannot be kept bailed out. In hauling our hay I purchased two old lake fishing boats (about 30 feet long) these are tied together and a rack put over them on which the hay is piled for hauling, then towed with a gas boat. The whole thing is very primitive, but it is a necessary expedient.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I wish to express our appreciation for the assistance which the Department has given the school in the supplying of hay for the wintering of our stock and the lumber for additions to the barn and for the building of the barge for hauling hay and wood. The assistance is particularly gratifying in these times of difficult school financing.

I am in a position now to make a full report on the matter. Our so-called "farm" at Hope Island is situated, as you may know, some five miles distant across Little Playgreen Lake at the entrance to the Nelson River. For two years I have had a family employed at this place taking care of the stock during the whole year. I found the situation impracticable, as it meant a duplication of services at the farm and at the school, where it was necessary to keep the milking animals. Also, during the break-up and freeze-up the farm was isolated for a considerable period of time. For instance, ice conditions this fall would have isolated the farm for about two months. Some land had been broken at Hope Island years ago and allowed to revert to sod. To put any crop in there in the spring would necessitate a double outfit of machinery and labour, one there and one at the school. About the only value the farm is to us at present is for grazing of stock during the summer.

It has been my objective to increase the herd of cattle to a sufficient number to supply milk to the school and the hospital, and also that the increase yearly should provide both these institutions with a complete supply of meat. In the short time of two years this has practically been accomplished, except that, owing to the necessity of depending temporarily on inexperienced Indian labour, the times of breeding have not so far been properly organized to ensure a steady supply of fresh milk. At the present writing we have butchered 10 head of cattle and 14 pigs, weighing 5391 lbs of beef and 2249 lbs of pork. This leaves us with 35 head of cattle of all ages, some of which we will butcher if necessary, and 11 pigs, 7 of which will be butchered next month. There are also 23 female goats and 2 male. I have previously told you of our bad luck in the breeding of these goats in the past two years. We hope for better returns of females next year. The goats are of excellent breed and are in good shape. They have been a full liability thus far but, now that I have accommodation for them here at the school, we can make better use of the milk next year. We also have some 150 pullets raised this year from chicks. These are now starting to lay. A chicken house 16' x 20' was built this year from lumber locally sawn from logs cut by the school.

From lumber supplied by the Department we have completed an addition to the barn 18' x 24' and also a building 12' x 16' for the housing of the goats. The barn itself needs inside renovation and this is yet to be done. I purchased a store building for $150.00 as additional accommodation. This building is in excellent shape and would be good value at $500.00. This has now been moved on to the school property. Altogether, the accommodation is now sufficient and I find it a distinct advantage to have the stock here at the school where it can be under personal supervision.

The supply of hay received from the Department will be sufficient, with the same 40 tons I was able to get locally, and the good crop of green oats harvested from the land here, to winter the stock through. With the high water this year, all hay had to be cut with scythes, some standing in water. I had to go as far afield as some islands in Big Playgreen Lake, 12 and 14 miles distant, for some of the hay. I do not know what the water conditions will be next year. I hope that more of the hay ground will be uncovered.

I appreciate also the supply of material for the building of the barge. This will be done before open water, in the warmer weather of the early spring. I have had to resort this year to the towing of two old fishing boats for the hauling of hay and wood, and it was a very slow process. The nearest fire-wood we can now get in any quantity is about a 12 mile haul. I find that it is much more economical to haul this wood by barge in the summer rather than have teams hauling during most of the winter. Much of the wood, especially dry wood, is down the Nelson River where it is almost impossible to put a team or a tractor owing to the fast current and resultant weak ice. I have had 200 logs cut for sawing into lumber in that locality since last winter, but have been unable to get them out without a barge. I will not be able to get these sawn until next summer and then the lumber will not be useful for building until it is dried for three or four months.

Incidentally, this condition considerably lessens the value of the local saw mill. It has not been possible to get a sufficient amount of dry lumber ahead so as to be available when needed. I have suggested that it might be profitable to provide an appropriation to the Agency to provide for the cutting of a large quantity of saw logs by the Indians so that dry lumber might be available when needed. The cost of rough lumber in Winnipeg is about $35.00 per M., to which is to be added $12.50 per M. freight. Lumber can be produced at the mill here from locally cut logs for $20.00 per M. The investment would appear to be profitable, as well as providing employment for the Indians.

Fish is practically unobtainable this winter. I am getting a small supply from Cross Lake for the school, but it is scarce there also. The fur also is scarce as this is one of the years the rabbits disappear. Should there be any evidences of destitution, which is quite possible before spring, a self-liquidating project such as suggested above would offset direct relief.

May I again express my thanks for your assistance,

Yours sincerely,

December 28, 1943.

P. G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Norway House, Man.

I have received a letter from Mr. Caldwell, Principal of the Norway House Indian Residential School, in which he advises that he has had about 200 logs cut for sawing into lumber, but has been unable to get the logs out, consequently will not be able to have them sawn until next summer at which time the lumber will not be useful for building purposes until it has seasoned.

He states that this condition lessens the value of the local sawmill. It has not been possible, he states, to get a sufficient amount of dry lumber ahead so as to be available when needed. Mr. Caldwell has suggested that an appropriation be secured to pay for taking out logs so that they can be sawn into lumber and a sufficiently large supply kept beyond immediate needs so that lumber will be available when required. He says that lumber can be produced at the mill for $20.00 per M. from locally cut logs, whereas shipped in to Norway House it costs about $55.00 per M. plus $12.90 freight.

In looking over the files I find that 7,000 ft. B.M. was cut last year for the refrigerating plant which was not built, and that the agency vote paid for the sawing of this lumber as well as for the taking out of the logs and operation of the mill during the time the lumber was being sawn. I also find that we advanced a sum of $200.00 for the purpose of paying for taking out 120 additional logs.

I should like to know how much lumber is on hand, how much of it is suitable for the school needs, how many logs were taken out, and all other information in this regard.

I should also like to know whether further assistance is required in order to keep a supply of lumber on hand at the agency, or whether there is some way this could be financed without departmental assistance.

Before replying to this letter I would suggest that you discuss the question with the Principal of the School in order to find out what his immediate needs are and future requirements in the way of lumber.

Acting Director.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to refer to the Acting Director's letter File 123-5-14 of December 28th last, regarding Mr Caldwell's comments in connection with lumber and the operation of our local sawmill.

At the present time we have no lumber on hand, and we have loaned to Mr Caldwell 2569 feet of lumber from the stock we did have, which he promised to replace. Part of the lumber loaned to Mr Caldwell came from what we had sawed for the refrigerator and part from lumber sawn from the advance of $200.00 from Welfare account as shown in the statement below. The amount of lumber sawn for the refrigerator was 7,000 feet.

With reference to the advance of $200.00, for taking out additional logs for lumber, I may say that of this amount I spent $100.00 for 100 logs delivered at the Agency, and an additional $18.75 for labour hired for sawing. Out of the 100 logs, we manufactured 4,740 feet of rough lumber, at a cost of $118.75, which works out at $25.00 per thousand feet. I have an unexpended balance in this account of $81.25. The following statement shows how the 7,000 feet of refrigerator lumber and the 4,740 feet of Welfare lumber has been disposed of:

With reference to the penultimate paragraph of the Acting Director's letter, I beg to say, that in order to provide a supply of lumber to be kept on hand at the Agency, it will be necessary for the Department to furnish financial assistance to cover the initial cost. In discussing this matter with our engineer Mr Stevenson, we figured that, with an advance of $1,000.00, we can manufacture, something over 40,000 feet of lumber in the rough. This would cover the cost of taking out 1,000 logs, hiring labour for sawing and hauling, and payment of the necessary Provincial Timber dues. We would figure on taking the logs from Sea Falls Island, which is about 17 miles from the Agency. This would involve making 20 trips with the Agency motor boat and barge. In connection with Sea Falls Island, I would refer to the Director's letter (No file number given) of

p.t.o.
September 10th, 1942. The work of taking out these logs would have to be undertaken as soon as possible, before the snow goes, so as to avoid swamping the logs over dry ground. Will you please advise me immediately if the necessary sum of $1,000.00 mentioned above will be provided by the Department. If so, it will be necessary to forward the amount in currency.

Once we have a good stock of lumber on hand such as the 40,000 feet mentioned, we will no doubt be able to keep this stock pretty well up by crediting the Welfare account with lumber used for Agency or Medical purposes, by charging these two votes at a rate of $25.00 per thousand, which is the cost of manufacture, and with the funds thus accumulated get out more logs and make more lumber. The land in the vicinity of Pine Creek is low and salty, and not well adapted for farming or even stock-raising, and even if it were, how could the proceeds of any industrial farm be...
As marketed. It would cost more than the value of the crop to bring it in to Westminster the nearest point to a railway station. The same remark equally applies to any article manufactured there. Sir,

I have the honor to recommend for your consideration the advisability of closing the R. C. Boarding School at Water Hen River Reserve, Manitowap Agency, and the transfer of the pupils of that institution to the school at Pine Creek.

My reasons for making this recommendation are that the two schools are only about thirty miles apart, and the desire of most of the parents that they would like the children to attend at Pine Creek where the facilities for taking care of the pupils is so much better than at Water Hen.

As you are aware the authorities of the R. C. C. have lately erected a very large and substantial school building at Pine Creek, with accommodation for 100 pupils, this school is operated by a number of Sisters of the Church under the management of Revd. Father Chaumont, and is in every sense a desirable institution for the training of Indian youth.

I have further to report that the closing of the Water Hen School meets with the approval of the Church, and it would appear that the new school building at Pine Creek was erected with the idea of gathering R. C. pupils altogether at that point.

Honorable David Laird,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.
From my own observation I have never been able to see why two boarding schools of the same denomination were located so close together.

As the Water Hen Boarding School is not named, or recognized, as such, by the order in council relating to the education of Indian children, 1894, under section II of Cap. 32, 57-58-Victoria, I presume you have full power to deal with the matter.

If this recommendation meets with your approval I would suggest that the school be closed at the end of the present fiscal year, and the per capita grant—if any—be transferred to the Pine Creek School, less sufficient to operate a day school at Water Hen, providing enough children of school age remain on the reserve to make it worth while.

Should you decide that it is not advisable to close the school I would strongly recommend that the Church authorities be advised to procure a new principal for the institution, as from my own observations, and reports received from undoubted authority, Mr. Adam, the principal—from his intemperate habits, and for other serious reasons, is unfit for the position.

For confirmation of this, I would refer you to Revd. Father Camper of St. Laurent, who appears to be the ecclesiastical head of Indian educational work in the district, and a man whom I think has the confidence of all who come in contact with him.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(sgd.) S. R. Marlatt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of above date regarding additional land for the Pine Creek Boarding School, I beg to say that the land upon which the school is at present located is 160 acres owned by the Church, and adjoins the reserve, consequently section 23 will be about 2 miles distant, and section 26 about 1 mile.

The school quarter section is not fit for agricultural purposes as it is one mass of boulders, small and large.

Undoubtedly it is township No. 34, not 24, that the Principal refers to.

If I may express my opinion candidly in the matter, I am averse to granting the school more land for agricultural purposes, because it is well known that those Indians are not inclined to agriculture. They take little interest in their gardens outside of potatoes, and it is difficult to get them to take care of their cattle during the winter.

The local district is not favorable to grain growing, as with the frozen lake on one side and swamps and marshes on the other, the springs open up too late for seeding.

The fishing and hunting are both good up there yet, with every probability of remaining so for many years.

The Honorable David Laird,
Indian Comm.,
Winnipeg.

Dear Sir,

Four weeks ago before Father Clement's death, I went to Pine Creek to examine with him the question of a second class-room and the isolation confirmaries, and after a very close examination of the situation we thought that a change in the distribution of the different rooms on the second floor would be a desirable improvement.

Having the class in the rear of the chapel as we have now has the considerable inconvenience of a very difficult access to it for the boys, so we thought that it would be far better to have it exactly above the first class-room, in the part of the building now occupied by the sisters. I have asked Agent Ogletree to let me have the full amount of this $140.00 at once so that I may invest it in milking cows now that they can be bought at a low price. Each Saturday a gasoline boat calls at this Reserve and collects Cream for the Winnipegosois Creamery. If I can get the money into my hands I can buy seven cows and by selling cream obtain a revenue of $12.00 to $15.00 a week. Sir:

Replying to your letter of November 27th last, it is unfortunate but true that letters addressed to the Indian agent Mr. Aglukkaq at Pointe La Prairie are seldom replied to and it seems are not given attention by him. This is the reason for communications being sent direct to you by —— this Band of Indians.
This Band of Indians.

With reference to the second paragraph of your letter relative to the Department policy in the conduct of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, there is no question that that policy is directly contrary to the desires of the members of this Band. There is absolutely no benefit to be derived from the attempt to teach Indian boys farming methods. Very little of the land of this Reserve is adapted to farming, being too low and wet. In addition Indians as a class...
never will become farmers. Their tradition, inclinations and environment here are such that their minds will never become trained to farming. This refers to this Reserve in particular. Here we are fishermen, trappers and hunters and such we will remain regardless of any attempt to teach our sons farming. Our sons require to be schooled and educated in the English language and methods of doing business in order that they may gain some knowledge of how to successfully cope with the white men.
in the marketing of fish and furs which commodities will remain our products here until the end of the chapter. For this reason it is desirable that our children spend the entire five days per week in the classrooms in exactly the same way as the children of the white people do, so that our children may learn reading, writing, arithmetic and business methods in the English language in exactly the same way as the children of the white people.
In my own case I am the father of two boys.
