LAND - Lots 1, 2, 3 and 4, Pine Creek Settlement in Manitoba, excepting surveyed road crossing the same and excepting from Lot 4 the part taken for public road and excepting Church grounds, leaving approximately 620 acres.

There are 86 acres under cultivation and 20 acres scrubbed ready for breaking. The soil is black mould from 4 to 10 inches in depth. The cultivated land is in very fair condition. The balance of the land is covered with scrub and some fair-sized trees, large enough for wood. There is considerable stone on the land. An area of the land, consisting of probably 50 acres, seemed to be rather low, but no water was on the surface.

Pine River runs through the land, and the property has frontage on Lake Winnipegosis. The buildings are situate about 300 yards from the Lake on one side and the River on the other.

BUILDINGS.

School building,- 115 x 50 ft. with 30 ft. studding, solid stone, metal roof. Full basement, steam-heated, lighted by acetylene gas. Contains dormitories and class-room, chapel, offices, reception-room and rooms for the staff and guests. Also, kitchen, dining-hall, store-room and laundry, etc., in the basement. It is fully equipped and in good condition. It is furnished throughout with suitable and substantial furniture, furnishing and fixtures.

The heating-plant is in good repair. There is also the lighting-plant, power for washing, churning and for water-supply which is piped from Pine River about 300 yards distant from the building. There is also a bake-oven with 160 loaf capacity.

Granary and Stable,- 101 x 24½, 12½ feet studding, two stories, frame with metal roof. This is a substantial building, double boards, and is used for stable on ground floor and granary on second floor. A portion is used at one end for a slaughter-house.

Barn and Stable,- 120 x 50 ft. with 13 feet studding, lean-to's at either end, one 14 x 50 ft., and the other 9-9 x 50 ft.. This is a good building, with harness-room, horse and cow stables and feeding-stables, a large cellar for root house, also mows for hay and straw with fork for unloading.

Machinery Shed,- 100 x 20 ft. with 8 ft. studding, frame, shingle roof. This building is used for storing the implements when not in use. Single board walls.

Other Buildings consist of blacksmith's shop, store-house, laborer's house, shed, poultry house and ice house. Also, a stone building used as a workshop.

All buildings are in a good state of repair and kept in a cleanly condition and do not show want of paint.

I estimate the value of the land, buildings and contents of the school building to be $102,648.00 and the implements and live-stock $6,100.00 making a total valuation of $110,748.00.
I found the implements to be in good repair and nearly all practically as good as new. The live-stock is also in good condition, and, in fact, everything about the place reflects credit on those in charge of it, and the estimates that I have given have been conservative throughout.

There is appended hereto a detained list of the contents of the school building, also detailed list of implements and live-stock.

Dear Sir:

With reference to our conversation with you yesterday, the position of this matter is, according to our information, as follows:

The Reclamation Branch of the Department of Public Works of the Province of Manitoba, sought to close the road lying to the North of Lot One in the Pine Creek Settlement and to open a new road along the South of Lot Four, and they arranged with your Organization to receive from you title to a strip of land along the South of Lot Four for the new road in exchange for which they were to give you title to the old road to the North of Lot One. A sale of the property was then arranged by you to the Department of Indian Affairs, but inasmuch as you had already given title to the roadway to the South of Lot Four you were unable to give them title to that part so transferred which was excepted from your transfer and you conveyed to them Lots One, Two, Three and Four, excepting from Four the new roadway, and you also conveyed to them by Quit Claim Deed your right to receive from the Province of Manitoba a conveyance of the roadway to the North of Lot One.

The solicitor for the Department of Indian Affairs at Portage la Prairie, raised some objections to your title to the roadway and the best arrangement that could be made with him was that he should release the money, retaining $1000.00 until the roadway title was made satisfactory. There have been several objections raised to the title, but we believe that all are satisfied save only that the title lacks a root. The Dominion Government roadways in this Province were vested in the Province under The Manitoba Supplementary Provisions Act, but in conveying these roadways the statute defined the roads as those shown on township surveys. The present road is shown on a survey of the Settlement of Pine Creek and not of a township so the officials here take the attitude that the title to the roadway sought to be closed is still vested in the Dominion Government and that the Provincial Government has not jurisdiction to close it. Provision is made in the

Rev. J.P. Magnan. #1
before mentioned statute for the Dominion Government to transfer roadways to the Manitoba Government by Order of the Governor-General-in-Council and we understand that the Department of Public Works here has written to Ottawa for an Order-in-Council from the Dominion Government vesting the roadway in question in the Province of Manitoba, whose jurisdiction to close the same will then be completed. It may be some little time until this Order-in-Council comes through and meantime, the solicitor for the Department of Indian Affairs, is holding up payment to you of $1,000.00. We believe that the Department of Indian Affairs were fully acquainted with the situation that they might be prepared to release the money and await completion of their title until such time as the Order-in-Council is passed. The amount of land involved is only a strip of land including in all some ten acres and is of little value. If the Department is not prepared to ask its solicitor to release the money perhaps it could exert some influence on the Department of the Interior to have the necessary Order-in-Council passed at an early meeting of the Council. The failure to give title is really that of the Department of Public Works of the Province of Manitoba, and is not the fault of any of the Departments at Ottawa, but no doubt they would be ready to co-operate to expedite the closing out of the transaction.

Yours truly,

PINE CREEK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

There is a boarding school on this reserve, run under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. This school was built by the Church authorities in 1900 but has recently been purchased by our Department. It is built of granite stone; the size of the building is 50 x 115 x 40, having a basement and three storeys. It is fully modern.

The number of pupils present was 61, 45 girls and 36 boys. There are two classrooms in the school.

The staff consists of the Principal, Assistant Principal, Blacksmith, Engineer and 7 Sisters.

There are also a number of outbuildings such as a stable, implement shed, granaries, pig-sty, carpenter shop, blacksmith shop, chicken house, ice house, store houses, etc. The buildings are all in good shape and were painted about 5 years ago.

The only defect I saw in the building was the shingles on the roof of the school, they have never been painted and are beginning to rot away.

They also have all the necessary implements as well as a Tractor and Threshing Machine. They farmed considerable land some years ago but this venture has not been a success as the land is very stony. They, however, raise an excellent garden here and had abundance of potatoes and garden truck.

They have 38 head of cattle, 12 cows which milk, so the children get lots of milk. They also keep pigs and chickens.

Everything was in good order around the school and the children looked healthy and seemed to be well cared for. The work in the classroom seemed to be satisfactory.

COMMISSIONER GRAHAM'S COMMENTS ON INSPECTOR CHRISTIANSON'S REPORT ON THE PINE CREEK IMPROVED RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,

Comm. Graham's letter dated Feb. 23rd, #208-9.

As the boarding school on this reserve is the property of the Department, the matter of re-shingling the roof should receive attention. You will notice that the farming venture at this school has not been a success in the past and I am of the opinion that it never will amount to anything. Stock-raising is the industry that should be encouraged at Pine Creek. The Principal, Father Brachet, is to be commended for the interest he takes in the Indians after they leave his school.

PINE CREEK RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.-This school is under the Roman Catholic Mission, with the Rev. Father Brachet, as Principal, who is assisted by a staff of some fifteen. There is a large farm and garden in connection with this school, and the Rev. Father Brachet has a large herd of cattle consisting among them some 20 head of young milch cows which allows the pupils plenty of good milk. The pupils of this school have always enjoyed good health and during the past year have not received any report of a serious nature. This school is situated in an open place between the bush and Lake Winnipegosis which helps to contribute to the health of the children. There is not any doubt but that the constant good health of these pupils is on account of the supply of fresh milk they are served three times a day. Most of these pupils look healthy and bright and appear to have a good time at the school, they are somewhat slow in speaking the English language, they want to speak their native language all the time if they were allowed. Dr. A.E. Medd, of Winnipegosis is medical officer for this school.

PINE CREEK DAY SCHOOL.-This school is under the Roman Catholic Mission, and taught by one of the Sisters from the Residential School, progress is reported fair in this school. There are II pupils on the Register with an average attendance of 7.

Pine Creek Boarding School

Situation: This school is situated on the shore of Lake Winnipegosis at the mouth of the Pine Creek. The P.O. address of the school being Winnipegosis, Manitoba.

Agency: It is in the Manitowapah Agency, Treaty No. 11.

Religion: It is a Roman Catholic school conducted under the auspices of two Franciscan Nuns, with a nun and priest as assistants. Rev. Father A. Chaumont is Principal.

Land: The land in connection with the school consists of 160 acres and is the property of the Roman Catholic mission.

Buildings: There consist of a new stone building 114 x 94 ft., 3 stories high built during the summer of 1899 at a cost of $2,000, of which the Dept. contributed the sum of $500. It was first occupied in the fall of 1899. The other buildings consist of stables, carpenter shop, and implement shed.

Accommodation: Accommodation can be divided for 100 pupils. The new school building...
is heated by a steam furnace. The water supply is obtained from the river by means of a pump.

History of School

The establishment of a reserve at Pine Creek was after much correspondence finally confirmed by order in Council dated Feb 8th 1894. The Indians moved from Duck Bay and settled on the new Reserve.

On the 5th January 1887 Rev J. A Dupont wrote the Deptt. asking that a Day school be built by the Govt. on the Pine Creek Reserve. In the annual report of the Deptt. for 1887 (Page 63-64) Agent Martineau says that a school was opened that year on the Pine Creek Reserve with one Herman Chartland as teacher who taught the school under the supervision of the Rev Father Dupont.

The first grant given by the Govt. towards this Day school was in 1888 when the sum of £25.5s. was paid to the teacher that year.

The Deptt. made a yearly grant of £300 towards the support of the day school and also a sum of £12.0s. per annum for each pupil in attendance over the number of 25. The grant to the Day school continued at this rate till the end of the year of 1897 when the Day school was run in connection with the Boarding...
School. The Estimates for 1897-98, 1898-99, provided a grant to the Day School for 100 pupils @ $2.00 per capita; and in the Estimates for 1899-1900, this grant was increased to 15 pupils @ $2.00 per capita and has been paid at that rate since then.

On the 21st June, the Dept. paid the sum of $6.03 for articles supplied to complete the school house at Pine Creek.

The Boarding School at Pine Creek was first opened during the year 1890 and was run in connection with the Day School. It was open during that year and the following year (1891) and seems to have been conducted during these two years & have been conducted in the old day school building.

During the years 1892, 93 and 94 the Boarding School was closed temporarily in order to put it on a better footing.

Early in the spring of 1893 it was decided by the Dept. to assist in the completion of a building which was partly erected by the Indians so as to afford suitable accommodation for a Boarding School. The cost provided for the work in 1893 was $500.00 and the Estimate in 1893-94 provided for $316.00 a total of $816.00.

Tenders were called for the work, two tenders were submitted, but both were considered.
to high.

On the 31st May, 1893, Inspector McColl was instructed by A.M. Burgess, Dept. of Interior, to proceed with the work of finishing and enlarging the school building at Pine Creek, the whole cost of which was not to exceed the sum appropriated viz.: $566.00.

The work was done by day labour under the supervision of a foreman and on the same specifications as were used for the Water Sheen River Bdg school.

On Dec. 6th/93, Inspector McColl informed the Dept. that the work had been completed according to instructions and forwarded vouchers for the work amounting to $598.52.

On the 8th January 1894, cheques were sent to Mr. McColl to cover the cost of the work amounting to $598.52.

The building when completed consisted of a log building 32 x 24 ft. with ceiling 9 ft. high.

The Boarding School re-opened Oct 1st/94 and has been conducted regularly since that date.

Mr. Joseph Marlett in his report on the
Boarding School at Water River
Conducted under the auspices of the
R.C. Church authorities gives it as his
opinion that the school should be closed.
His reasons being that the attendance
is irregular and that the school is not
necessary on account of the proximity
of the Pine Creek Boarding School and
that better results could be obtained
from one large, well conducted school
than from two small ones.

He advocated the amalgamation of
the two schools of Water River and
Pine Creek, and that the grant to the
latter school be increased and the
pupils at Water River be transferred
to Pine Creek, thus leaving only a
day school at Water River which
would be sufficient for the need of the
Indians at that place.

The Archbishop of St. Boniface, the Rev. A.
Chamoux Principal of Pine Creek and
the Indians themselves were favourable
to the scheme.

The Water Hen River Boarding School was closed Sept. 30th, 1900 and the pupils thereafter transferred to Pine Creek Boarding School.

A Day school will be maintained at Water Hen River as long as sufficient pupils attend to warrant its being kept open. It will receive the usual Day School grant.

The Reserves which are benefited by this school are: Sandy Bay (Res. No. 1), Pine Creek (Res. No. 4), Lake Manitoba, Elbow and Floe Lake, Fairfield Little Saskatchewan, Lake St. Martin Crane River and Water Hen River Reserves in Treaty No. 2. It is estimated that there are 285 children of school age on the above reserves. There are Day schools on all the Reserves.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days' attendance of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount of per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly-per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residences of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. Where, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days residences of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Dear Sir:

Taking up matter treated in your letters of July 20th, 1916 and August 11th, 1916, with reference to water supply at Pine Creek, I beg to state that Rev. Fr G. Leonard and his successor, Rev. Fr Brachet, have tried unsuccessfully to bore artesian wells at eight different places, but without satisfactory results.

Your letter of August 11th, 1916, mentioned that the Department was ready to pay the necessary railway charges in connection with the moving to and from the school of well boring machinery and in the event of the well not proving satisfactory the amount could be expended in the construction of a concrete reservoir for water supply.

I herewith join freight receipt for bringing well boring outfit to Winnepegosis.

Now to return the said outfit charges will be quite higher, as railway charges have increased and the destination is different.

Rev. Fr Brachet is presently digging a canal for water supply of the above mentioned school and states that this canal will cost around $1500.00. He has requested me to ask from the Department if he could not receive any substantial help in the matter.

Hoping to receive a favourable answer, I remain

Yours very truly,

What is Globe Triangular Steel?

The steel we offer differs from cast, wrought and "M" iron or steel, due to the amount of carbon and other ingredients used in its composition, thus securing the requisite toughness, tenacity, hardness and elasticity. In forming our TRIANGULAR STEEL STANDARD nothing is left but the best American Sheet Steel, pickled and cold rolled and formed into triangular shape under tremendous pressure by special machines designed for the purpose.

The TRIANGULAR form of construction was adopted after most exhaustive tests, it being a well-known scientific fact that the Triangle is the most important figure in geometry, and may be considered the element of all other figures. The method of steel fabrication used in the construction of the Steel Sanitary Desks offered by us is original, and by the use of special machinery, precision dies, insures lightness, strength and rigidity. The completed product, welded together electrically into one solid, indestructible finished article. It eliminates all sharp edges and bacteria pockets. It is SELF-EVIDENT that the construction of the GLOBE STEEL SANITARY DESK is not accomplished by merely buying the rough steel and assembling it by bolts and rivets. The steel has been subjected to every well known scientific test to determine its tensile, breaking and abrasive or friction qualities, and will withstand extraordinary conditions of usage.

Why Our Desks Are Sanitary

Hygienic, sanitary desks are demanded today, and our TRIANGULAR form of steel construction affords no lodgment for dust or dirt. All filigree work, so necessary in cast iron construction has been abandoned, and book boxes with the exception of the top and bottoms, being made of one solid piece of steel, giving more room and security for school utensils. The feet of the desks are stamped and cold drawn from the solid steel standards and occupy the minimum amount of floor space, and, having turned flanges, afford a close, tight-fitting, substantial joint and support on the floor. This permits no opportunity for the accumulation of dirt and bacteria. The same dust cloth used on the tops will cleanse the metal work from every particle of dust.

The woods are regularly finished a rich CHERRY COLOR, but where necessary they may be finished with the natural color for the back and seat and cherry top.

Guarantee

It has been customary to guarantee the ordinary cast iron desk from five to twenty-five years, but this does not protect the purchaser from the expense and annoyance of replacing breakage or paying cost in transportation and labor in setting up, or defective and noisy hinges. We have eliminated by the use of the Steel construction all weaknesses such as breakage, noisy hinges, etc., and we give all purchasers of Steel Sanitary Desks, an additional guarantee against breakage for a lifetime.

PINE CREEK RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

There is a boarding school on this reserve, run under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. This school was built by the Church authorities in 1900 but has recently been purchased by our Department. It is built of granite stone—the size of the building is 50 x 115 x 40, having a basement and three storeys. It is fully modern.

There are also a number of outbuildings such as a stable, implement shed, granaries, pig-sty, carpenter shop, blacksmith shop, chicken house, ice house, store houses, etc. The buildings are all in good shape and were painted about 5 years ago.

The only defect I saw in the building was the shingles on the roof of the school, they have never been painted and are beginning to rot away.

They also have all the necessary implements as well as a Tractor and Threshing Machine. They farmed considerable land some years ago but this venture has not been a success as the land is very stony. They, however, raise an excellent garden here and had abundance of potatoes and garden truck.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th inst., relatively to precautions against fire and to say that we will do our best to follow your wise directions. In the same time I am sorry to state that the present fire escape facilities are not adequate, also that the fire hoses are rather in a poor condition, and finally that the engine room in the stable is dangerous.

1- Fire escape facilities.

There has been up to now only one fire escape. Access may be had on it on the third story only from a room situated between the boys' and the girls' dormitories; this room has to be kept locked on both sides so as to cut out all possible communications between boys and girls. On the second story access may be had only from the girls' infirmary. Furthermore this fire escape consists of an iron staircase, which in winter may be slippery with ice and therefore not completely safe.

2- Fire Hoses.

At my last inspection of the fire hoses I found out that they are no longer very effective for the reason that they have been kept folded from the beginning, instead of being rolled over a rack; the creases, through heat and time, have had the rubber inside to split.

3- Engine room in stable.

Our pumping plant is situated in the stables, where we can easily draw the necessary water for the school and stables. Still an engine remains dangerous, especially in stables, where hay is kept on the loft and around. We have an isolated room with a cement floor, but fire may catch on the partitions, which consists of boards.

I would suggest, for more security, the following changes, which I ask the Indian Department to kindly consider, and if found proper and opportune, to have them ordered as soon as possible with the required assistance.

1- New Fire Escapes.

I would recommend doing away with the present Fire Escape and building 2 new ones of pipe with platforms. I have found the pipe escape giving easy and prompt evacuation in other schools. One pipe fire escape could be set to give directly access on the boys' dormitory on the third story, and on the upper class-room on the second story.

Dear Sir:

I beg to make reference to your welcome letter of August 17, 1927, No. 126-1-5, in which we are authorized to renew the roof and gutters of the school for the sum of $1200.00, and to say that the work is now completely finished.

Here is what we have done. We have torn off the old shingles and the mortar on which they were laid; we have laid No. 1 Shingles on first class roofing paper; the shingles we have painted with two coats of black Valdura Asphalt Paint; we have put new and larger eave-troughs and gutters. We have also profited by the fact that we had the scaffolding to paint in white the garret windows (3 coats of white lead) and the other windows of the school (2 coats). Seeing again that the outside window sills were rotten, we had them replaced by cement sills.

We have done a first class job, which could not have been obtained by contractors, seeing that every shingle was put properly. The work has changed the appearance of the school one hundred per cent.

Although we have obtained more than reasonable wages, the total amount of expenses went over the sum of $1200.00 to reach the total cost of $1,678.97. When we have made the estimates for $1200.00, we had in mind to use for stain Lamp black with Linseed Oil. It would have cost only $48.70. Since we have met with a very good product used by the best store of Winnipeg, the Hudson's Bay Co., to wit, the black Valdura Asphalt Paint, which cannot be surpassed for painting shingles, for the fact that it gives a lasting color of great preserving qualities and that it spreads under the covered shingles. We were told that one barrel would extend for two coats, but we found out that two barrels were needed and ordered another barrel and express in order to finish the work before frost. I had borrowed Linseed Oil from local stores and I gave them back from the ordered barrel. The two barrels of Valdura Paint and barrel of Linseed Oil came to $286.90 and the work, to be thoroughly done, was considerably longer than for application of stain. The fact of painting the windows extended also the expenses, but we thought it could not be left out since the scaffolding was up.

One thing I can say is that no better material could be bought and that it could not be found under cheaper rates, also that no other men would consent to work for such low wages, a part being given gratis, lastly that the work could not be done any better by anybody.

Therefore I feel that the Indian Department should be over satisfied and will make no objection to pay the expended amount. I have promised to settle before the end of the month.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

December 3, 1927.

Memorandum:

You will remember that the Rev. Principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School proposed to renew the roof and the eaves of the main building for the sum of $1200 - the Cusson Lumber Company, of St. Boniface, Man., were to cooperate in this undertaking, which was approved by the Honourable the Superintendent General. While you were in Western Canada, the Rev. Principal wrote to the effect that he could secure better prices by dealing with firms other than the Cusson Lumber Co. who he stated, did not seem anxious to take the work. As the building season was well advanced, he stated that he was proceeding with the work, following the lines of his second proposal. As somewhat different authority had been given him, I could not approve of his action, but I did not care to cancel all authority, for two reasons - the improvement was urgent and it was evidently being effected in as economical a manner as possible.

The accounts are now to hand and are as follows:

| Description                                      | Amount   |
|--------------------------------------------------|----------|
| Ashdown Hardware, Winnipeg - Materials           | $590.07  |
| Standard Lumber Co., Winnipegososis, Materials   | $407.20  |
| James Wright, Winnipegososis, - Materials        | $186.50  |
| Rev. Principal, Camperville, (a) Freighting      | $58.80   |
| (b) Labour                                       | $436.40  |
| **Total:**                                       | **$1678.97** |

The Rev. Principal reports that the old shingles and mortar have been torn off, No. 1 shingles laid on first grade roofing paper and the shingles painted with two coats of Asphalt paint. New eave troughs and gutters have been put on. Certain additional work was done, as the school management wished to profit by the presence of the scaffolding. All windows were painted and the outside window sills, which had rotted, were replaced by cement sills. The Principal further states that first class materials only have been used, that suitable labour was engaged at the best possible rates and that the school's appearance is now improved 100%.

$1500 was provided for improvements at this school - reshingling and new eaves $1000; painting $500. If you are satisfied with the manner in which the work was done, I recommend the payment of the accounts.

Sir,-

I beg to inform the Indian Department that a member of my staff, Origène Bourbonnière, wanting to make in a hurry the new fire escapes allowed by the Department, and being short of acetylene, condensed some himself for soldering, but the second time he put too much pressure and the tank burst, a piece of which struck him above the eye. We had to bring him hurriedly to the Dauphin hospital, where an operation took place in which his left eye was taken out and the fractured forehead put back in place. The poor man may lose the other eye; his case just now is considered desperate; but we will do our best to save him. Unfortunately my funds are now completely exhausted, and I wish the Department would help me a little to pay the hospital and doctor's bills.

Hoping to receive a favorable answer, I am, Sir,

to incur the expenditure required in lining the inside of

costs to be kept as low as possible and that the school
should do the work without cost.

I have communicated with an expert of the
J. H. Ashdown Hardware Co. of Winnipeg to find out the
cost of asbestoslate and asbestos paper and to know
the best material which, at lowest costs, could be used
for safely lining the engine room in a permanent way.
I was advised that on account of water in the engine
room, where the pumping of water is done, and on account
of lower cost and better service, Galvanized Iron should
be used. 40 Sheets of Asbestos Mill Board would have
been required, the cost of which, at 1/8 in. thick came
to $29.00 - which thickness was hardly satisfactory -
at 3/16 in. thick, the cost would have been $44.00.
Therefore I have ordered and used Galv. Iron.
The work has been all completed, and the engine room
is now completely safe against any possible fire
through gasoline or sparking.

I beg to refer to my letters of August 2nd, 1926, August 22nd, 1927 & October 17th, 1927 written to the Indian Department through Mr. A. Ogletree, Indian Agent of Portage la Prairie, Man., in order to have some of the floors of the school renewed. I have to state that these floors have become very bad and that I am now ashamed to bring in visitors to see the school. Furthermore other floors are wearing out, such as the floor in the junior recreation room on the girls side. The amount I had asked was $435.00 nearly two years ago (on August 2nd, 1926). This amount would hardly be enough now, except I can purchase birch flooring at special prices at the Standard Lumber Co. - Winnipegosis- Man. This birch flooring would last nearly as long as maple. I was trying to deal last year with the said Co. and they were ready to give me very good bargains for the fact that few people are asking for it just now.

I would be very thankful to know if the Department has included in the estimates of 1928-1929 the sum of $435.00 for the renewal of our floors and to be allowed to proceed with the work shortly.

In the same time I beg to remind the Department that I had asked for the inside painting of the school which has not taken place for the last 15 years. I understand that this item was also to be included in the estimates for the amount of $500.00.

Ottawa, May 10, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, with reference to flooring and interior painting that is required at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. I am pleased to inform you that the Deputy Superintendent General has approved of carrying out these improvements this year. Funds were provided in our Estimates for the purpose. You may purchase the necessary quantity of flooring from the best source of supply. It is understood that you will buy as reasonably as possible and that the expenditure for the flooring and for the labour will not exceed $475. I will forward to you, under separate cover, labour returns, which should be kept in duplicate, showing the time and the receipts of the men employed. The members of the staff and any of the older boys at the school that assist should give their labour without payment. The account for flooring, in duplicate, should be certified by yourself and forwarded to the Department for payment, with an explanation concerning any other tenders that were received. When we are in receipt of the labour returns, showing payments that you have made to whatever men are engaged, a cheque will be directed to you in reimbursement.

With reference to the interior painting that is required, I have to request that you will prepare a list of the materials needed and will call for prices from the best sources of supply. You should forward them with your recommendation concerning the purchase, and indicate if school labour could do the painting. The Department suggests that one competent painter be engaged to oversee the work. You might let me know if you can secure the services of such a worker.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Manitowapah Agency, which shows that the work is being carried on satisfactorily. There are several matters, however, that require the attention of the Department.

The tanks in the Pine Creek School should be replaced, either by a pressure tank, or by new elevated tanks. I would recommend the pressure tank. I would strongly recommend that the lighting plant be changed at once. It is most dangerous to have acetylene gas around a place.

The fire hose at the Sandy Bay School should be replaced.

I am not in favour of having the van system put into effect at the Dog Creek School. It would only end in failure. The residence at this school should be condemned and a new one built as soon as possible.

A small lean-to building should be added to the Lake St. Martin School. The cost will be about $400.00—not more than $500.00, and perhaps a lot less.

I do not know what salary Mr. Wheadon and Mr. Garwood get, but apparently their work is as important as that of other teachers in this agency, and if the Department could see its way clear to give them a living salary I should be glad. You will note what the Inspector says regarding the matter of remuneration for Miss Billy Gorman, who stays with her sister at the Ebb & Flow School.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

PINE CREEK

I reported fully on this school two years ago. The Principal is the Rev. Father J. Brachet. There are eighty children attending the school. The school-building-

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
building is of stone, and is in a very fair state of repair, with the exception of the storage for water, and the lighting. The water is pumped from the river by a gasoline engine into six storage tanks, three of which are situated in the centre of the building up near the roof. Two are in the girls' dormitory and one in the boys' dormitory. These tanks filled with water in the centre of the building are, naturally, quite a strain on it, but this is not all, they are now practically useless, and a change will have to be made, as they are continually springing a leak and the water coming through the ceiling and down through the plaster does a lot of damage, and the sooner these tanks are replaced the better. The question is whether the tanks should be replaced by others of the same type, or a pressure tank placed in the basement. There is a place in the basement which could be utilized for this purpose if we decide to install a pressure tank.

I also wish to bring to your attention the matter of the lighting system. This school is lighted with acetylene gas, and in the past two years there have been two explosions. Last winter an explosion took place which very nearly killed the Engineer, and it is a miracle that it did not. One eye was completely knocked out, and his face was badly burned. There are still open wounds on his face from the effect of this, although he spent three months in the hospital. In my opinion the school should be wired for electric lighting, and a plant installed. If the Department should decide to do this, the installation of a pressure tank and lighting plant could be carried out at the same time. A new engine would have to be supplied, as the one in use now would not be large enough. The engine that pumps the water is in the stable, which is
situated about half way between the school and the river. It draws the water from the river to the barn, and then by pressure from the pump, from there to the tanks in the school, and is distributed throughout the school from the tanks by gravity. I was three days on this reserve, but as it was during the weekend when the school was not in session I did not have a chance to examine the classrooms, but I had a good opportunity of meeting the Indians and seeing what was going on around the school and on the reserve. I must say that I was very favorably impressed with the Principal, the Rev. Father Brachet; he is highly respected by the Indians, and has a great influence on the reserve. What pleased me more than anything was the fact that I could see the influence of the school wherever I went on the reserve. This, no doubt, is what the Department expects on every reserve, but you are aware in how few cases it can be seen. In this place, however, it is very noticeable, and it is largely due to the Principal. There are numerous outbuildings at the school, all in a fair state of repair, but very little has been done in the way of repairs for the last few years, and an item should be placed in the Estimates for general repairs; it need not be large, as, if the material, etc., is purchased, the school authorities will do the necessary work. As regards fire protection I may say that the fire apparatus is in good shape, as everything has been renewed and there are sufficient fire extinguishers and hose to meet the requirements. A door opens from the two dormitories out onto a platform, and from there a sliding pole leads to the ground. Fire drill -is held-
is held regularly once a week, and, in my opinion, everything possible is being done to guard against loss by fire.

Dear Sir:

In answer to your letter written at Winnipegosis I have to say that I am very sorry that you have been unable through uncontrollable circumstances to come and visit our school and staff. I hope that during the next holidays we will have the pleasure of meeting you and of discoursing about Indian education.

In your letter you suggest that I should write you this month letting you know what we need most. After due thought the Rev. Sisters and I have decided that the most urgent need to fill is a BREAD OVEN. We have presently a huge brick oven, the top of which is unsafe on account of bits of bricks falling down regularly, and which let a thick smoke escape throughout the kitchen and the whole school during the baking operation, thus making the stay in the kitchen most unbearable, and exposing us to fire, should the top fall in a mass while fire is on. The gift from the Department of a good oven would be a great change for our school and would be deeply appreciated by the girls who have to keep crying while making bread, on account of the dense smoke. I am sure that, if you wish to use your influence, you would be able to obtain one good oven for us from the Department.

The Dacust "Economy" Oven gives constant satisfaction. I have seen one at work and the town baker who uses it says he would never part with it or consent to have a brick oven in its place. We would need the Size 4 Wood burning Oven $400.00.

Hoping you will be able to encourage us with this gift, I am, Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 27th September last, No. 126-1-5, and my reply of the 4th instant, in connection with the matter of a water supply and lighting for the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, I beg to say that I am now in receipt of a complete report regarding the water situation and the lighting and I would strongly urge that this work be completed at once, if the Department can find the funds, as it would mean a great deal to this school. As far as the water is concerned, all that is needed is the renewing of the present tanks. This would eliminate any charges in changing the pipe system, and the cost would only be $250.00. The installing of a lighting system which would be ample for their requirements would cost $1943.00, plus the board of men while installing, which would be a small matter. Mr. Sharpe, the Manager of the Delco Company here, who is an authority on lighting, made a trip to Pine Creek under difficult conditions in order to give this matter careful consideration, and I am satisfied that if the authority is given, the situation will be cleared up at this school and everything can be put in good shape before winter sets in. I should be glad if the money could be made available so that we could take advantage of the investigations that have been made.
