REPAIRS & IMPROVEMENTS

needed

at the PINE CREEK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - CAMPERVILLE P.O., Man.

- II - IMPROVEMENTS -

1- Water Tanks (compressed air)
The present water tanks, made of galvanized iron, are worn out through rust, and expose us often to inundations, thus spoiling the new floors just obtained from the Indian Dept.

Electric Plant.
We have now acetylene light; the machine is old; the system is defective and dangerous.

2- Bakery.
a) Oven (Size 4 D'Acoust "Economy" Wood Oven.
b) Bread Mixer.

We have no bakery. The oven we use now is situated in the kitchen, thus giving fearful heat in a place already too hot. It consists of a brick oven, which falls in pieces, thus being dangerous for fire, as it close to the ceiling, and it let escape a terrible and annoying smoke all throughout the school.

We have no bread mixer.

3- Laundry.
a) Power Washing Machine. (Beaver)
b) Steam Boiler.
c) Extractor.

We have no laundry accommodations whatever. There is an old washing machine, which is worn out and does not clean the linen properly. We have no drying machine for the clothes.

H.B.- There is no room in the school for all these apparatuses. A new building would be necessary, to have all the machines together, working, as much as possible, with the same power.

This building could be big enough to leave space for:

1- A Dairy Room. We have none.

2- Employees' dining room and bed room. We have only a small room for them, and we intend to extend the boys' recreation room in it.

3- Drying Tumbler, which we could ask from the Dept. later, and which could be installed near the laundry.

4- Frigidaire, which could be asked from the Dept. later.

Thus anything that would be installed could be set for good, without need of alteration in the near future.

Sept. 30, 1928.
REPAIRS & IMPROVEMENTS

needed

at the PINE CREEK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - CAMPERVILLE P.O., Man.

1. Renewal of all inside Sewer Pipes & Water Closets.
   The Sewer Pipes are clogged up with alkali deposits; they have been pierced in several places in order to free them temporarily; these openings are not hygienic.
   The closet working apparatus is worn out with rust and use in every place.

2. Installation of Bath Rooms, with water closets, in the middle room between the boys' and girls' dormitories. Three bath-tubs are required for the boys and as many for the girls.
   The present bathing accommodations are downstairs in the open and are not adequate.

3. Installation of a large recreation room for the boys. It could be put in the basement, where presently we have a shoe repairing shop, and comprise in the same time the employees' dining-room and a part of the refectory.
   The present recreation room is on the ground floor with too many exits to facilitate supervising, and specially it is altogether too small for the number of boys who can hardly move around to play, and have no place therein to be taught manual work.

4. Installation of a common recreation room for the girls. It could be put in the basement, where presently we have a little laundry, and could be extended to comprise the pantry.
   The girls have now two recreation rooms, one for the big girls, another for the small ones. These recreation rooms are small and necessitate uselessly the attendance of two Sisters.

5. Installation of one dining room for the Fathers, and of another one for the Sisters. It could be put in the refectory, which instead could comprise the small girls' recreation room.
   The pantry would be found very convenient quite near the kitchen, where the Sisters' dining room is now. As we have competent Sisters to take charge of the pupils during their meals, they can teach them better how to eat and behave at table, if Fathers have a private dining room outside of the refectory.

6. Installation of one parlour for Indian parents. It could be put where actually we have the boys' recreation room and comprise a part of the senior class room, which instead could take the big girls' recreation room.

N.B. - These changes would mean removing of partitions and installation of others. It would also be necessary to have the stairs going from the basement to the ground floor built in a different way, so as to pass along the recreation rooms on both sides of the building without disturbing the pupils.

These changes are necessitated in view of accommodating the pupils and facilitating a proper and constant care of every one of them.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that the Very Rev. Father Provincial has handed to the Department, today, your list of the improvements that are required at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. The Department intends to place an amount in the Estimates for this purpose; but, in the meantime, it is considered desirable to have a definite proposal from you concerning the best method of having two of the improvements effected. I refer to the alterations in the basement - Nos. 3 to 6, on page 1 of your list. Please let me have an estimate of the cost of the materials in this connection and indicate what expert labour, if any, it will be necessary to engage.

I should be glad if you would let me have a rough sketch of the proposed laundry addition - such laundry to house a power washing machine, a steam boiler, an extractor and later, a drying tumbler. I do not believe it advisable to have a dairy placed in the same building as the laundry, and I wish you would seriously consider the suitability of such an addition for employees' living quarters, before making a recommendation. Please let me know whether this building should be of stone or of frame and if you could supervise its construction on a day labour basis. You might also give me an estimate of the cost.

The Department is not prepared to favourably consider the supplying of a frigidaire, as this requires considerable electric power. It is not our practice to supply water softeners either. I may say that Mr. Commissioner Graham, next spring, will be given authority to complete arrangements in connection with the electric plant and lighting and the renewing of the water tanks. When you are considering the alterations in the basement, you should keep in mind the advisability of allowing room there for the electric plant.

Your obedient servant,

I am glad Mr. Graham did not install a Delco at Pine Creek School this fall. A Delco is not sufficient at St. Philip's; it would be still less at Pine Creek. A year ago we have installed a double plant, Lister-Bronston at our ecclesiastical College at Lebret, but as they are now served by the provincial plant we could dispose of the bigger one, just the thing that would suit Father Brachet. The engine is a 20 H.P. and the generator develops 6 K, 120V. The cost was $2600.

The Department may prefer to buy a new one, but it is important to install a good one that will give satisfaction.
Dear Sir:

Reverend Brother Eugene Gauthier has been working for nearly a month at Pine Creek Indian Res. School, inspecting the building and drawing sketches for the proposed alterations and improvements. I beg to submit to you his report in full.

After a thorough inspection of building and equipment my remarks are that the conditions of the building itself are good, except for the sagging of the center part, on account of the weight of the water tanks for the school supply. As can be seen on the second floor plan, one tank only is in that center part; but there are also two other tanks immediately above in the attic to supply the dormitories.

The capacity of the tanks in the attic is 1200 gallons and the one shown in the center of the dormitory is 500 gal., making a total of 1700 gal., a weight of nearly two tons—exactly 17850 pounds. These tanks should be removed as soon as possible for the safety of the building.

In 1912, the longitudinal center partition, shown on the Basement plan, has been raised, and a new concrete foundation built under it. There is too much on it besides the floors above and the roof. Provision therefore should be made for pneumatic tanks in the proposed addition.

I have also noticed that the complete sewer system are clogged with sediment and alkali contained in the water. The cast iron sewer pipes, in the building, have been bored in a great many places to insert cleaning rods, and these openings are simply stopped with wooden plugs, which endanger the sanitary condition of the school. This system need to be done over entirely.

The Basement floor plan shows the present condition of the laundry, which in itself is altogether too small, where, in addition to laundry equipment, several other machines have been installed for want of proper place. The present washer, which is the only mechanical laundry apparatus is a homemade machine built eighteen years ago, consequently worn out and entirely inadequate. A complete set of modern machines in a proper place are an urgent necessity.

Owing to the present system of sewer disposal which leaves the building at 24" above the basement floor, it is impossible to drain same and impossible also to have lavatories on that floor. It would be advisable to have the septic tank and other sewer disposed of towards the River, to West, for the following reasons:

1. The grade towards East is not sufficient to permit drain below basement floor;

2. The building of an addition on the east side, which is the only available place, is possible only if it can be dug to the present basement floor line. Otherwise it would mask the windows in the class room consequently only drain towards the River, west, can permit this;

3. Since the River water is not used any more by the inhabitants even for watering stock, and since we will eventually have to bring the water from the Lake for the School, it is not advisable to continue to dispose of the sewer in that direction;

4. The present cesspool and septic tank are in the way for the
proposed addition, and the cost of making this change would not be very great because there is actually a good drain that was laid for this event some years ago when renewing the water line to stable. Only the septi tank and inside drain are the necessary extras.

It might not be out of place here to say a word about the River water used at present in the school. I was told at Pine Creek that this water is so bad as to cause death to animals, which have no other place to water. Everybody drive their stock to the Lake for watering. I have brought samples of said River water and also sample of Lake Winnipegosis water (in sterilized bottles) to the Provincial Board of Health for analysis, which brought the following report: River water, hard, Colon Bacilli present; Bacterial count 4000, not fit for domestic purposes. Lake water, soft, Colon Bacilli, non-bacterial count 3000; good drinking water. Signed: Dr F. Cadham.

Of course this River water is used only for sanitary purposes (Kitchen and other domestic use is ice water), but since the River water is the only kind in the house taps I have seen some pupils using it for drinking against the warning. The only remedy to this condition is to bring the water from the Lake. In the long run it will be less expensive. A profile of both grades West, in the front of the School towards River, and East behind the School towards the Lake will give a clear idea of this possibility.

The boys and girls play rooms are inadequate. The girls rooms are large enough, but are too far apart. The boys room is too small altogether. The changes shown on the respective plans would improve this situation.

The removal of the water tanks in the dormitories (which need to be renewed) while relieving the building of their weight, will also provide the necessary bath accommodation.

A hot water tank is also necessary. At present, for bathing and laundry purposes they are using steam to heat one of the tanks in the attic, which is very objectionable on account of the steam escaping from open tank.

The present lighting gas plant is old and a constant danger. The same machine has caused an explosion some years ago and has been remodelled and installed in another place, but the danger is always there because it is impossible to have the Calcium Carbide of a uniform size to avoid over-generating at times. A good electric plant should replace the present system. With reference to an electric plant it is very important to use a system where the generator itself carries the load, because the current used is drawn from the battery alone there is a loss of at least 30% in best condition (and more as the battery wears away) from storing and drawing from the battery.

On the next page you will find the approximate cost of addition, improvements and alterations. The Pine Creek School is in pressing need, and I ask you to give kindly to this matter a most favourable consideration. Rev Brother Gauthier will supervise the whole work and see that it is properly done.

Yours devotedly,

Dear Sir:

On my return from the West I find Mr McLean's letter of the 23rd ult. with reference to improvements at the Pine Creek Res. School. I regret to say it gives no consolation to all concerned.

If you look over your records, you will notice that Pine Creek School has received less than any other school under our charge. Allow me to say, with all due respect, that these improvements should be done without delay as the situation, at Pine Creek School, seems to be almost intolerable, particularly for the good Sisters. Do you remember I have mentioned to you that the Oblate Sisters is the 3rd Community to take charge of the pupils, and that the material conditions had much to do with the departure of the Benedictine Sisters last August.

According to Mr McLean's letter, only a sum of about $9,000.00 is available for Pine Creek, and the question to be decided is—how should it be expended. The improvements contemplated are so linked together it is a difficult task to make a choice. The requirements of Pine Creek School are all so pressing that it would be perhaps advisable to reduce the appropriation granted to other schools of our Province, unless you get a special allowance in the supplementary estimates.

If absolutely impossible to have all the work done this year, I would suggest the following as more urgent:

1. New addition for Laundry,
2. Laundry equipment,
3. Change of septic tank,
4. Alterations inside the Building.

For these only a sum of about $13,000.00 would be necessary, and no soft water supply. Brother E. Gauthier had drawn a sketch for a larger Laundry Addition, but, on my advice, he has reduced its size. I am very doubtful it could be smaller. I understand the steam boiler mentioned is to supply the power for all the laundry machinery.

Hoping you will give this matter a favourable attention, I remain,

Yours devotedly,

J. Magnan, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

Reverend Fr Chagnon, Principal of Sandy Bay School, has willingly accepted to wait till next year for the construction of a barn, and consequently, the appropriation of $4,500.00 that has been made for that purpose could be transferred to Pine Creek School.

Unfortunately, things are not going so smoothly with Lebret. According to the information I have received from Reverend Fr Léonard, work on the Laundry could not be delayed. The boiler is in a very bad shape and all the flues must be replaced as soon as possible, one or two going out of order every week. Mr Graham has refused to renew the flues this spring.

The Sisters would not consider my proposition. Three years ago they have asked Mr Scott to have an addition built to the Laundry, because the boiler, the engine and the coal bin being located close to the machinery, proper work could not be done and the linen was often soiled.

The Reverend Principal would be satisfied with an addition and some new laundry equipment, at the cost of about $5,000.00, but this is not Mr Graham's plan.

What will be the fate of Pine Creek School? I still hope the Department of Indian Affairs will make a special appropriation for this school as its requirements are the most pressing.

Sir,-

Re: SCHOOL BOILERS.

On the 29th ult. Mr. J. L. Fuller, Provincial Boiler Inspector, of Dauphin, has come to inspect the school boilers. I beg to enclose his report in duplicate.

"This boiler was placed in the school 30 years ago and has now become so thin around the back head that it sprung a leak last winter.
In examining the back head I found that all the back head above the tubes was so thin that it would sink under the hammer at any point."

Therefore a new boiler is necessary. As I understand that Bro. Eugene Gaither, O.M.I., is coming in a fortnight to direct some repair work in our school, and as he has full experience in boiler repairing, opportune it would be, I think, to have the new boiler shipped as soon as possible, that he may install it fittingly. Saint-Boniface, Man. August 12th 1929

Dear Sir:

I am leaving today, with some men, to start work at Pine Creek Boarding School. I would appreciate very much if you would use your influence towards the Department of Public Works to have the dredge at Winnipegosisis to assist us in digging the channel in the Lake for the intake pipe. The Lake is quite shallow and we will have to go 400 ft, probably more, to get a sufficient depth of water to prevent freezing.

It will be a hard proposition for hand work, for the shore is coarse sand and gravel.

I have seen Mr Goodspeed, District Engineer, Dominion Public Works, in Winnipeg, to that effect, and I hope it will be possible, especially if this is recommended by some Official at Ottawa.

Will you also be kind enough to see that some money for wages be sent to me, together with some labor return forms.

The work is progressing satisfactorily at Kenora. The Addition to the School and the boat-house will be finished in about six weeks time.

With anticipated thanks,

Yours sincerely,

Bro. Eugé Gauthier

Camperville, Man.

August 19th, 1929.

Dear Sir,

This Department is about to undertake the reconstruction of a water supply system at one of its boarding schools at Pine Creek, Man. This work is being carried out under the direction of Brother Eugene Gauthier, who has just advised me that your Department has a dredge at Winnipogosis.

As it would be necessary to excavate a channel in the lake on a distance of about 400 ft. for the installing of an intake pipe, your Department would render a great service in giving the necessary authorization to Mr. Goodspeed, your District Engineer of Winnipeg to have the above mentioned dredging performed in co-operation with Brother Gauthier who is already on the site of the work with a number of workmen.

I might say that the reason for going such a distance into the lake is due to the shallow condition of the shore and the necessity of preventing the intake pipe from freezing in the winter time. The nature of the soil where the work is to be carried out is coarse sand and gravel. I should appreciate very much if you would advise me at an early date of your Department's decision concerning this matter.

Yours very truly,

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Chief Engineer,
Department of Public Works,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 28th August last, concerning reconstruction of a water supply system at one of your Department's boarding schools at Pine Creek, Manitoba, and requesting this Department to excavate a channel of about 400' in length, for the installation of an intake pipe, Mr. Goodspeed, our District at Winnipeg, Manitoba, has reported in part, as follows:

"Our original information was that this dredging was some 400 to 600 feet long and 6 feet deep. When the dredge arrived there dredging was requested for a distance of something like 1500 feet and to a depth of 10 feet. This occasionally happens. Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
Camperville P.O., Man.,
October 8th, 1929.

Sir,

Re. improvements at Pine Creek School.
No. 126-1-5. Letter, Sept. 10, 1929.

I beg to acknowledge receipt on the 15th ult. of a cheque of $2,000.00 from the Department to pay labour in connection with the improvements of the Pine Creek School.

I am herewith forwarding to day in duplicate the labour pay sheets from August 14th to October 5th for digging and filling a trench from the school to the lake for the water pipe, also for the digging and filling of a new septic tank and trench for the outlet pipe from the school to the river. The total amount is $2,494.30, to wit:

| Date   | Amount |
|--------|--------|
| Aug. 17 | 76.75  |
|        | 148.60 |
|        | 229.40 |
|        | 272.85 |
|        | 85.50  |
| Sept. 7 | 212.00 |
|        | 61.15  |
|        | 265.10 |
|        | 196.50 |
|        | 70.25  |
|        | 65.85  |
|        | 92.50  |
|        | 88.50  |
|        | 144.50 |
|        | 198.75 |
| Oct. 5  | 216.75 |
|        | 16.00  |

$2,494.30

I beg you to note that we began the work just when the fall fishing season started on Lake Winnipegosis. The men at that very time were rather scarce, some others had gone for harvesting, and it was impossible to obtain then lower wages. Immediately after the end of the fishing, that is from September 19th, we dropped the wages $1.00 lower.

You will notice also that I have signed myself the pay sheets for the Indian Agent, who is situated too far from here: Portage la Prairie is 200 miles away. I had asked him to come and inspect the work, but I suppose he was too busy overlooking the threshing on reserves around the town.

I forward in the same time receipts in duplicate for disbursements regarding the improvements, to wit to:

A. Pelletier $8.00 for lumber,
J.N.O. Bourbonnière 68.40 for hauling material etc.,
C. Chartrand 210.00 for hauling gravel,
J. Pangman 6.90 for filling lime kiln,
C. Chartrand 59.00 for hauling wood to lime kiln,
E. Guiboché 24.50 for firing lime kiln,
J. Desrochers 40.00 for driving Bro. Gauthier to Winnipegosis relatively to
$411.60 lumber, other material and freight.
The gravel and lime are for the addition which we start to build. Some gravel has been used for the septic tank.

The total expenditure up to now is then

$2,906.10

Pay sheets $2,494.30
Receipts $411.80

$2,906.10

You then see that we have advanced the sum of $906.10. I would, therefore, be thankful if you would send me immediately a cheque of $1,500.00, to have the amount of $906.10 reimbursed and also to pay the few labourers we are still keeping for the construction of the addition for laundry, bakery and electric plant.

I remain, dear Sir,

Sincerely yours,

Notes on improvements made at the Big Creek Residential School.

Dredge work. It has been insufficient. The dredge has stopped at 150 ft. from the shore, the digging being there only 4 ft. The digging has started at about 1000 ft., where 7 ft. of water have been found over the hard pan, which rises gradually towards the shore. The machine, not being strong enough to penetrate the hard pan, has dug only the soft ground, which covers the hard pan, so that the work after all is not very useful, and we shall have to dig by hand to complete it, if we are not able to dynamite it.

Sewer Pipe. The Sewer Pipe, which was supposed to be used for the septic tank and which we believed to be low enough, had to be abandoned, first from the fact that it is only 5' 4" under the ground level and thus does not permit the draining of the wash room, furthermore from the fact that it is only 4" dia. and at the point where it has been uncovered, the sloping level did not show enough.

From this the necessity of another canal of a length of 650 ft., down to the river. This canal, near the septic tank, is 8' 2" deep; at the road, in front the school, where the ground is higher, it is 9' 3" deep; from there it lowers gradually down to the river with a declivity of 6" per 100 ft.

We have needed for this canal 650 ft. of clay pipe, 6 in. dia.

Stones. All the work of digging, towards the lake for the inlet pipe, as much as towards the river, as outlet for the septic tank, has been rendered more difficult on account of the great quantity of stones contained in the ground. In places these stones were so big that we had to break them in order to pull them out or sink them to the bottom in digging a deeper hole.

Hard pan. This digging was also made harder on account of the hard pan which is found everywhere at a depth of 3½ or 4 ft. The pick had to be used everywhere, penetrating ¾ in. only at a time.

Water Pipe. The inlet water pipe is 1800 ft. long and is laid at 9 ft. deep for 50 ft. from the shore up to a manhole cemented with a wide wooden cover and put at the back of a gravel bank near the lake shore. The pipe then raises to the level of the lake, to wit at 4' 6" deep all throughout the muskeg with a gradation of 2 in. per hundred ft. up to the school, thus reaching a depth of 10 ft. near the addition; it rises to the surface in the machine room.

Sewer system in the school. The sewer system having been condemned by a sanitary expert has to be renewed entirely. It is then more economical to do the work in the same time while the new sewer pipes are set in the laundry, thus cutting out the traveling expenses of pipe fitters.

Steam Boilers. The only steam boiler left from the old installation had to be reset according to the report of the boiler inspector, and it was necessary to move it closer to the new boiler, asked by the said Inspector. Happily, in a way, it was discovered thus in time that one of the two side supports was corroded by rust, which menaced to corrode the boiler itself. This support was replaced by one of the supports of the condemned boiler.

New chimney. An expert found out that the inadequacy of the heating system proceeded from the small diameter of the chimney flue.

REPORT OF LABOUR ON IMPROVEMENTS at Pine Creek School
since week ending August 17th, 1929 up to date.

DIGGING FOR WATER PIPE LINE (special 3 in. galv.)
from new building to lake.

Trench 3 ft. wide x 1975 ft. long, excavated to a depth of 10 ft. at the building and continue with a down grade of 2 in. per 100 ft., across the ridge, and through the marsh.
The latter is dug at an average of 4½ ft.

At the bank of the lake there is built a concrete box 6'x4'x4' deep, with a 24 in. man-hole to provide room and access to two 3 in. gate valves and 3 in. check valve between the two gates. The top of man-hole has been kept 24 in. below top of bank and is covered with marsh loam level with the bank.
Sand concrete box and man-hole are provided with double covers (with 10 cm between).

Past the concrete box there is a drop with 45° angles to 6 ft. below actual water level.
From lake shore to where the dredge dug (approx. 180 ft.), we have made a coffer-dam with clay and we have excavated said distance and laid the pipe on same level and filled over.

This concludes, for the present, the extent of laying the pipe. When the lake will be frozen sufficiently, we intend to build a wooden coffer-dam to cut the clay bank between trench and excavation by the dredge, and continue the digging, from the top of the ice, at the same level, as far as necessary to complete the work which was supposed to have been done by the dredge.

LAYING OF PIPE AND FILLING OVER.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART,

It has been found necessary to make improvements to the heating, water supply and sewage disposal and to provide a laundry building with modern equipment at the government-owned Pine Creek Indian Residential School, on Lake Winnipegosis. The original estimate was $25,600; but, when our Estimates for the current year were prepared, it was thought that less would be needed this fiscal year, and an item of $12,800 was included. The Oblate Order has undertaken the work, under the supervision of Brother Gauthier, who is one of their best mechanics. The repairs and improvements were found very urgent and have been undertaken in a businesslike manner. It is now necessary to give a little more assistance. Fortunately, the Appropriation for Indian Education can stand an additional charge of $5,000, and I propose, with your approval, to so inform the Oblate Order. I am informed that it would be very inconvenient to take the lay Brothers and others off the job at the present time. An item in next year's Main Estimates will provide funds for the completion of the work. The main building will then be thoroughly modern.

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Father Magnan:

On the 20th instant, Father Brachet and Brother Gauthier forwarded reports on the improvements that are being made at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. Sir,

Re- No. 126-7-5

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st inst. relatively to the improvements which are authorized for the Pine Creek School, and to state that I have received the cheque of $1,500.00 which you have directed for labour, also that on the 20th inst. I have forwarded to the Department a report signed by Bro. Gauthier, O.M.I., of the labour and improvements performed at the Pine Creek School since the week ending August 17th, 1929, up to the 20th of November, together with the estimates of the complete work, amounting to $29,639.02.

It has already been represented to the Department that the work is so linked together that it is impossible to do one part without the other. Again Rev. Fathers Guy and Plourde, O.M.I., have brought to the attention of the Department the fact that the work is very pressing for the river water which we are using up to now is unsanitary, the old washing machine is unsafe, as well as unsatisfactory, the water tanks in the attic are worn out with rust, the old acetylene generator cannot last any longer. Therefore it is very necessary that, as soon as possible, the addition be finished in which are to be installed the new water tanks, the electrical plant and the new washing machines. Of course it is understood that the estimates of about $30,000.00 are in the same time for the years 1929 and 1930.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J. Bracken, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Saint-Boniface, Man., December 16th 1929

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have your letter of the 5th inst., referring to improvements that are being made at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, under the supervision of Rev. Brother E. Gauthier. I note that the total Department's grant available this year for these improvements is $17,800.00, and that the Oblate Fathers are requested to provide for all expenditure over this amount, but with the understanding that the Department will try to secure an item for reimbursement next spring. I beg to say that this arrangement is satisfactory to us, the Banque Canadienne Nationale having accepted to advance the necessary credit.

The Building itself is surely worth the proposed expenditure. In fact, Pine Creek School is one of the best schools under my jurisdiction and is giving the best results.

I wish to assure you that I greatly appreciate your efforts in this matter, and I feel indebted to you for having avoided the great inconvenience of postponing the work until next spring. I wish also to thank you most cordially for the splendid allowance you have made for Muscowequan School.

Yours very truly,

March 4, 1930.

Sir,

Re: Fire protection.

I beg to let the Department know that on the 25th ult., the house of our main man has burned to pieces. If there had been a fire extinguisher in the house, the fire would probably have been checked in time, whereas we had to content ourselves with the few we had in the school, and during that time the fire was out of control thus causing a loss of $1,500.00. The house was sold to the Department together with the school and other buildings, but since it had been greatly improved at our expense.

Considering that the Cross Lake School has burned the same day, and that we cannot have too much fire protection, I think it advisable to ask the Department to furnish us soon with

14 FIRE EXTINGUISHERS,
4 of which with unfreezable liquid.

5 Fire Axes,

Sir,

I beg to let you know that on the 25th ult., the house in which our factotum was living has completely been destroyed from a chimney fire, which had become uncontrollable, notwithstanding all our efforts. The house belonged to the Department since the sale of the school and dependent buildings, and with the betterments given it lately, its value was over $1,500.00.

Now, as the Department must know, we are far away from communications and a good general man, such as we need here constantly, cannot accept to live away from civilization centres without having at least some compensating advantages, the main one of which is a good house.

Presently we are fortunate enough in having a good man, who knows well engines, blacksmithing, general repairing and even acetylene welding, and who is heartily devoted to the interest of the school and pupils, whom he teaches in his trades, and if the Department does not give him a house, he cannot accept, on account of his family, to stay any longer in our midst.

Just now we have able carpenters who, under the direction of Rev. Bro. Gauthier, O.M.I., could build a good and substantial house, when they are through with the improvements carried on at the school. As you are aware, a good house cannot be erected for less than $2,500.00.

Rev. Father J. Magan, O.M.I., Provincial, St. Boniface, Man., came to see us about this sad event, and he is earnestly in favour of this request; in fact he intends to see the officials of the Department about the matter.

I wish, therefore, that the Department would have pity on us and grant the sum of at least $2,500.00 towards the erection of a simple, but comfortable house for our general man, Mr. O. Bourbonniere.

I have, Sir, the honour to be

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Rev. [Signature], O.M.I.,
Principal.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant and I note, with regret, that the employee's house at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School has been destroyed by fire. There are no funds available at the present time to make replacement of this building, and I do not know when an appropriation could be secured. The Department is hopeful that funds will soon be available for the completion of the improvements that are now in hand; but I regret I cannot authorize any additional expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

Sister Superior Agnes-Emilie, I would be deeply glad if the Department would obtain for us or permit us to purchase the following material:

4 gal. Diamond "A" Floor Paint, Color: Terra Cotta

6 " Floor Ground Color
2 " Kyanize All Purpose Varnish
5 " Light Oak Kyanize Floor Varnish

3 gal. Turpentine

2 Putty Knives
2 Wire Scrapers

Ottawa, May 16, 1938.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, requesting authority to purchase the quantity of paint, varnish, brushes, etc., mentioned therein to be used in redecorating at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure in the purchase of the materials to an amount not exceeding the sum of $150, and will pay accounts covering the cost up to that amount. You should arrange for the purchase of the materials, obtaining itemized accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost. These you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department, when payment not exceeding the above authorized amount will be made.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir:

Re. Hired Man's house.

Rev. Father J. Magnan, O.M.I., Provincial, St. Boniface, Man., writes me that at his visit at Ottawa, he has been assured that the sum of $3,000 would be included in the estimates for building a house for our hired man. I beg to say that we have presently working at the improvements of the school a very able and reliable carpenter, who has worked at the trade all his life after a thorough apprenticeship. He does quick and neat work. We do not know a better man in Manitoba or Saskatchewan. He is to go away as soon as the improvements of the school are finished.

Owing to this fact and also to the fact that our main man wants to leave, if he is not given a house soon - it would be very hard to replace him - I would ask you to use your influence that I may obtain from the Department the authorization to start the building, after we are through with the other works.

Hoping to receive a prompt reply, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Rev. [Signature], O.M.I.,
Principal.

Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

Re. No. 126-1-5.

I beg to refer to the last part of your letter of November 15, 1928, in which you state that the Department is not prepared to favourably consider the supplying of a frigidaire, as this requires considerable electric power.

Owing to the fact that we cannot have a frigidaire, I wish the Department would make the small expense of supplying us with a KITCHEN REFRIGERATOR. We experience considerable trouble at this time of the year in keeping food from one meal to the other. A medium size refrigerator would be of a great use for us all the year round.

During summer we have a lot of visitors, who come and look with interest at all our work regarding the Indian wards. Some time it is proper that we serve a little dish to some visitor of mark; but owing to the lack of refrigerator, we cannot treat immediately our honourable visitors as we would wish to.

I hope, therefore, you will consider favourably this request, and buy one refrigerator for us or authorize us to buy one.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Bracken O.M.I.,
Principal.
Ottawa, June 20, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, relative to the erection of a house at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School for the hired man. In this connection I have to inform you that it is regretted the item to provide the funds required for this purpose was disallowed in our Estimates, and we will, therefore, be unable to authorize the erection of this house this year. An item will, however, be noted for our Estimates for the next fiscal year.

I have also your letter of the same date relative to supplying a kitchen refrigerator. In this connection I have to say that the Department will provide an amount not exceeding the sum of $100 towards the cost of a medium sized refrigerator. After you have made the purchase of this equipment, you should forward an account, in duplicate, certified by yourself, in the usual manner covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

DEAR SIR,

RE. No. 126-1-5.

In reply to your letter of the 2nd inst. regarding the Laundry Stove, I beg to say that arrangements had been made last year verbally between the Indian Department and Rev. Father Guy, O.M.I., in the name of Rev. J. Magan, O.M.I., Provincial, St. Boniface, Man., to the effect that a complete Laundry Equipment would be set at the Pine Creek School, owing to the fact that we were very miserably equipped with only a worn out washer. Consequently Laundry Machines were bought by Rev. Bro. Gauthier, O.M.I., Supervisor of the works here, and the accounts were sent to the Department on November 24th, 1929, to the amount of $2,250.00. At the same time Rev. Bro. Gauthier had ordered from the same Company a Laundry Stove, but on account of different misunderstandings and inexplicable delays it came only lately.

This stove is indeed singularly high in price, likely from the fact that only a few of this make are sold. It is destined to heat the irons which the girls are to use for ironing. It is very unsatisfactory to have a tiny stove for such a purpose, as then there is no end to the work. With this stove we shall be able to finish the ironing quickly, for from 10 to 15 girls will be able to iron in the same time, as it contains up to 30 irons.

Owing to all these facts, I am hereby returning for acceptance the duplicate bill of BEAVER SOAP & CHEMICALS, LTD. - WINNIPEG - MAN., amounting to $280.00, which I will be very thankful if you would have the kindness to pay to the Co.

I will also be grateful if you can reimburse me the amount of $8.00, which I have paid for freight, to wit:

From Winnipeg to Winnipegosis $5.96
From Winnipegosis to Campbellville 2.18

Yours very sincerely,

Rev. J. Gauthier, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

Re. 126-135 Dec. 6, 1929.

In my letter of the 8th inst. concerning the last labour returns relatively to the improvements carried on at the Pine Creek Residential School, I mentioned that the accounts of YATES, NEALE & CO., 231 Tenth St., BRANDON, MAN., were to follow. Other items from the same Co. will follow soon.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J. Strachan O.M.I.,

October 20th 1930

DEAR SIR,

Re-FIRE PROTECTION --

I beg to inform the Department that we had unhappily the misfortune of losing the beautiful Church that had been erected 20 years ago and was the object of admiration for all visitors coming to our distant wilderness.

It was by chance that we succeeded to protect the School building itself; owing to fact that the walls of the both buildings Church and School that were of stones, that no wind could spread the fire, and above all because we had powerful means to struggle the fire. These means were the high pressure watering system that the Department granted us last winter and the numerous extinguishers.

If now we have to deplore only the loss for the Church Authorities of the substantial building that belonged to them, we have to think for the future.

In consideration of the distance from all civilization and of the danger always imminent, I have taken the liberty of reordering REFILLS for all our extinguishers that were exhausted and of a certain number of canvas hose that proved too short.

I have no idea of the approximate of price for same, but I expect that the Department would not blame the initiative taken by one who don't wish to see our work destroyed in a trice as well as the beautiful and well equipped school trusted to our care. Moreover I would appreciate to be authorized for this purchase.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brackett
Principal

Saint-Boniface, Man. October 27th 1930

Mr Duncan C. Scott, D.Litt.
Deputy Supt. General.
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr Scott,

The sad occurrence that has happened lately at the Pine Creek Indian Res. School impels me to look for a greater safety of the Indian Res. Schools under our management. A vicious boy named Francis McKay, only 15 years old, has thrice attempted to set the School on fire and has confessed his crime. He was foiled in his criminal design by the vigilance of the watchman who had been appointed immediately after the burning of our church, the 27th of September. The fire was set, very likely, by the same boy.

He has been expelled from the School, but it occurs to me that a more adequate punishment would be in order. He could be apprehended by the police and sent, at least, to a correction school.

I am pleased to inform you that the new improvements, especially the new water-works, have given a good service during the fire. It was an easy task to save the School. With the old system it might have been impossible.

So many accidents having taken place in different Indian Schools, it is no wonder that the principals and sisters are living in constant alarm, and I feel it is my duty to bring them relief as much as possible. It is a known fact that some Indian children will not hesitate to set a fire in the hope of going home. The best way to protect lives and buildings would be to have a watchman in every school. The new schools will all be fire-proof, but a watchman would give the old ones the protection they need. As the financial burden of our Indian Schools is already heavy, too heavy, I respectfully suggest that the Department of Indian Affairs grant a special allowance for this purpose.

Hoping you will receive favourably my request, I remain,

Yours devotedly,

November 3, 1930.

Dear Father Magnan:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the recent fire which destroyed the fine church at Pine Creek. I am very glad that the new water supply system gave the protection the school building needed. The Department will allow a grant of $40 a month for a night watchman at this school. It is understood that he must constantly patrol the building, from bedtime to rising bell. This grant will be payable to you, upon receipt of a voucher, say, twice yearly.

With reference to Francis McKay, the 15 year old boy who has been setting fires, I am writing to Mr. Indian Agent Waite, asking him to discuss the matter with the local detachment of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. I dislike sending an Indian boy to a reformatory, but it appears that, in his case, some corrective measures are necessary.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Sir:

The Very Reverend Provincial of the Oblate Order, when writing to the Department regarding the recent loss by fire of the church at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, refers to one of the pupils in the following terms: "A vicious boy, named Francis McKay, only 15 years old, has thrice attempted to set the School on fire and has confessed his crime. He was foiled in his criminal design by the vigilance of the watchman who had been appointed immediately after the burning of our church, the 27th of September. The fire was set, very likely, by the same boy. He has been expelled from the school, but it occurs to me that a more adequate punishment would be in order. He could be apprehended by the police and sent, at least, to a correction school."

Will you please discuss this case with the local R. C. M. P. and, if you believe that the boy should be apprehended and placed on trial, you should so advise the officer commanding the local detachment. If the facts are as represented, I believe that a term in a reformatory would have a good effect.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Report Re Fire at Camperville, Manitoba.

The fire occurred at about 5:00 a.m. on September 29th, 1930, in the church building owned by Les Reverends Peres Oblats.

The building was 150' x 50' and was built of stone and roof of sheet metal, being heated from central heating plant outside the building, and lighted by electricity.

The building and contents are insured as follows:-
Policy No. 621028, in the Ocean, $4,000 on building, and Policy No. 458173, the Royal Insurance Company, $8,000 and $2,000 on contents, total insurance on building and contents of $14,000.

The contents were valued at about $7,000 and are a total loss, the building being valued at $28,000 with a loss of $21,205. The total loss sustained by this fire being in the vicinity of $28,000.

On making inquiries in regard to the fire it was learned that O. Bourbennier who is the engineer on the property was awakened by his wife who informed him that there was a light in the church. Bourbennier's residence being about one hundred yards distance. On looking out of his house he observed it was a fire and he ran to the school building and sent in the fire alarm in the school and then rang the church bell.

On entering the church he could see no fire but the church was full of smoke.

On being advised of the fire Sister St. John, who was residing in the school building, rushed into the church with two fire extinguishers, entering by the side door into the vestry room at the back of the altar. On arriving there she found the cupboard holding the vestments on fire and a fire burning on the south side of the cupboard. There was also a flame on the floor. She operated the extinguisher and extinguished all the fire at the bottom of the cupboard. The top of the cupboard was about a foot from the ceiling and it was still burning. She could see no fire on the inside of the church with the exception of this fire in the cupboard.

The Rev. C. Comeau, Assistant Principal, was sleeping in the school building on the morning of the fire and was awakened by the alarm. He rushed over to the church and observed a fire behind the altar. He immediately gave orders and superintended the operation of the fire extinguishing apparatus and an endeavor was made to check the fire, but it appears that one of the couplings on the hose was defective and it was pulled apart and by the time
the men got the hose repaired and in working order the fire was beyond control.

It might be said that the Mission at Camperville consists of a large three story stone school building, containing a large number of pupils all being Indian children, a number of farm buildings and the church destroyed, and being under the charge of the Rev. M. O. Bretagne, C.M.I., Vice Principal. The Rev. Father Bretagne was absent in Winnipeg at the time of the fire.

This fire was investigated by Inspector Fuller, Resident Inspector of the Fire Commissioner's Branch at Dauphin and no cause could be found for the fire and there was a suspicion that the fire was not of accidental origin and inquiries were being continued.

On the 15th of November Inspector Fuller received a communication from the Rev. Father Bretagne, dated the 11th of November, requesting him to come to Camperville as there had been a new object of fire which might have some connection with the church fire.

On receipt of this communication, the writer accompanied Inspector Fuller to Camperville on Thursday the 20th of November and commenced an investigation.

On our arrival Father Bretagne informed us that a fire had been discovered in the furnace room of the school on the evening of Monday the 10th November and that on smelling smoke he had made a search for the fire and found it in the furnace room burning on partition between two studs. He extinguished this fire with a fire extinguisher.

On making an inspection of this fire it was found that the fire had its origin between the cordwood pile and the partition and had travelled up towards the studs and from the nature of the burning it would appear that it had got a good start before being discovered and that it was only through the prompt action of Father Bretagne that the building was saved from destruction.

The fire, it might be stated, was discovered just about 6.00 p.m. as the pupils were commencing supper.

From the conditions existing and the time the fire occurred we had a suspicion that this fire had been caused by someone in the building, and on the following day ten of the pupils were questioned by the writer, no one being present in the room but the pupil under interrogation.

At about 3.30 in the afternoon the writer was able to obtain from Roger Napakisit or Flatfoot, an Indian boy, fifteen years of age, a confession that he was responsible for the fire. The boy states that he had been painting part of the building that day with a number of other boys and when the bell rang at a quarter to six...
they all proceeded to the wash room and discarded their overalls and washed their hands. This boy states that after he washed his hands he left the building by the side door in the wash room and ran around the building and on his way he picked up some small pieces of wood, carried them in his hands and went to the furnace room. He found the furnace room door open and he entered and placed the wood that he had picked up in about the center of the cord wood pile against the partition. He then opened the door of the furnace and took a thin piece of wood and lit it by the flame and placed it in the chips which he had placed in the cord wood pile against the partition. It started to burn and he ran away leaving the door of the furnace open.

He then entered through the door leading from the recreation room and entered the recreation room. There were no boys there when he entered this room and he then ran along the corridor to the refactory where dinner was being served and was the last boy in the refactory for dinner. He states he set this fire because he did not like the school and wanted out to work.

Father Bretagne also informed the inspectors that about three weeks ago a fire had been discovered in the closet of the school building and on making inquiries they suspected a boy named Francis McCoy, an Indian boy aged about fifteen.

On being closely questioned by the Rev. Fathers the boy at first denied all knowledge of the fires but on the Fathers making a promise to him that he would not be punished but that he would be dismissed from the school, the boy admitted setting three separate fires in the building, two being under the stairways and one in the closet. However, on the position of these fires being pointed out to the inspector it was found that they had done no damage and had apparently died out of their own accord.

In a statement to Father Bretagne, the boy told him that the first fire he had set in the school was two days after the fire in the church.

In view of the promise made to the boy, the Fathers feel that it was their duty to keep this promise and the boy was sent home to his Father at Duck Bay. However, before leaving for Duck Bay, Constable Bayfield of the Provincial Police happened to be at the Mission and was informed of what had occurred and the Constable then took McCoy before all the pupils and gave them a warning against setting fires in the school.

After a confession was obtained from Roger Napakisit Inspector Fuller and the writer accompanied by Father Comeau proceeded to Duck Bay in order to have an interview with Francis McCoy, who had been responsible for the three previous fires in the school, and it might be said at this time he had denied all knowledge of the fires in the church to the Fathers. However, feeling that this boy might be responsible for the fire in the church it was thought
necessary to have an interview with him.

On arriving at Duck Bay, the boy was closely questioned by the writer in the presence of Inspector Fuller when he finally admitted setting the fires in the church.

He stated that he found the matches in a box in the cupboard behind the altar in the school chapel and that he started a fire in the dust box which was lying in the cupboard where the boy's cassocks were kept and some of the priests' vestments and that when he dropped the match into this box he closed the door of the cupboard. On being questioned as to why he had set fire to the church he said that he was lonely and that he did not want to go to school but wanted out to work and that he thought if there was a big fire in the church that it would catch on to the school and burn the school.

As regards the two boys who are responsible for these fires, it might be said that they are both about the same mentality and the impression gained by the writer is that they are not bright boys and that they are the big boys of the school and feel it having to associate with the smaller boys and would rather be out working.

It is difficult to determine just what punishment should be meted out to these boys responsible for the fires, and on discussing the matter with Rev. Father Bretagne, the conclusion arrived at was that no good purpose could be gained by laying a charge of arson against them, and having them brought before the courts and probably sentenced to a term in a detention home. The boys, in this event, would be out of their natural element and a continual watch would have to be kept over them as there is a probability they would make an attempt to destroy their place of detention.

In view of these conditions I would, therefore, recommend that the matter be left in the hands of the church authorities to deal with the boys as they may see fit. Father Bretagne assures me that these two boys will not be allowed to return to the school.

It might be stated that the school building is the property of the Dominion Government, and under the charge of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Investigator.
December 1st, 1930.

Superintendent,

Sir:-

Re: FRANCIS McKAY, Indian Juvenile, Camperville, Man.

Arson

First report:

I have the honor to report that during the latter part of September, 1930, the Roman Catholic Church at Camperville, Man., was destroyed by fire. The matter was investigated at the time by Insp. J.L. Fuller of the Manitoba Fire Commissioner's Department and it was found that the origin was incendiary. Investigation revealed the fact that one, Francis McKay, an Indian boy, aged 14 years, an inmate of the Pine Creek Reserve Indian Residential School, which adjoins the church, had deliberately set the fire for the express purpose of being expelled from the school. He made a written confession to Insp. Fuller. No action was taken by the authorities at this time.

Regarding this matter I recently received a letter from Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man., enclosing a letter addressed to him from the Dept. of Indian Affairs relative to the advisability of prosecuting Francis McKay and having him committed to a reformatory. Apparently the Catholic Church authorities wished this action taken.

In order to acquaint myself with the facts I endeavoured to gain the privilege of looking over Mr. Fuller's file in conjunction with the Manitoba Provincial Police who were interested in the matter, but in due course was advised by Sergt. G.A. Renton of the Manitoba Provincial Police, Dauphin, Man., that the matter was in the hands of the Attorney General who was in communication with Ottawa respecting the prosecution of Francis McKay under the Juvenile Offenders Act. Mr. Waite was so advised.

Nothing further has been heard of the matter up to this time, but presume the prosecution will be proceeded with in due course.

The Church in question is the property of the Oblate Fathers of Mary Immaculate and stood on property belonging to the Church on the outskirts of the scattered village of Camperville.

Further report to follow.

Camperville, Man.
The classroom work is carried on in two classrooms under the supervision of Sister Pierre Celestin, who has charge of the children in Grade I & II, and Sister Marie des Anges, who has charge of Grades III, IV, V & VI.

The junior room has an enrolment of 39, and the senior room 49. The classrooms were well aired, tidy, and clean. Neither of the Sisters have Normal training, but the senior teacher has taught for some years.

The children were all well clothed, very clean, and exceptionally tidy. I was delighted with their appearance. They were bright and cheerful, and replied freely when questioned.

The school throughout was in excellent condition, and scarcely a particle of dust could be found. The dormitories were well aired, and the bedding was clean. Each child is supplied with a toothbrush, glass, and towel, all of which are undoubtedly used. A number of the beds have no springs, and the mattresses are placed on boards. Springs should be provided.

The laundry
The laundry is in the new wing of the school, and is one of the best equipped I have visited. The laundry work seen had all been well done, and the girls are receiving an excellent training in this work.

The kitchen was tidy and, as usual, I found it a busy place. The range has burned out on one side, and I would judge is past repairing. At present only one oven can be used, consequently the Sister is greatly handicapped in her work. This is a heavy department, and I believe a larger range would make the work less difficult. The present range has only one fire box, and with about 100 to cook for, the stove is continually loaded down, and it is a difficult matter to properly serve the meals.

The sewing room is well equipped, and the children learn to do all kinds of plain sewing, mending and darning. The work seen in this department was all well done, and the training should be of wonderful value to the girls.

The fire equipment is in excellent condition. Extinguishers are placed in prominent places throughout the building, and axes and pails are hung at various places. Fire drill was observed during my visit, and I believe is carried out regularly as the children appeared to know what was expected of them. The water pressure is good, and is well looked after by a good mechanic. A night watchman is kept, and a punch clock is used with stations throughout the building.

The children were all fat, and in good physical condition. They receive porridge, bread, lard and tea for breakfast. Potatoes are also served at times. Dinner consists of
PINE CREEK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

consists of potatoes, carrots or turnips, meat or fish, bread, and rice or tapioca pudding. At supper time they again receive potatoes, or a stew made from meat and potatoes, all the bread they want, and milk or tea. Butter or lard is also served.

A large stock of cattle are kept, and six cows had already freshened. The cattle are well cared for, and plenty of feed remained. A trench silo is in use, and a quantity of ensilage remained. A number of brood sows are kept, but the younger pigs had been butchered. Chickens are also kept, and were receiving excellent care, with the result that plenty of eggs were being obtained.

The Rev. Father Brachet was absent during my visit, so I did not meet him. I was delighted with the condition of the school and the management, and I believe it is one of the best I have visited. The school was spotless, the children were healthy and fat, and I believe excellent work is being accomplished.
Regina, Sask., April 28, 1931.

I consider it my duty to make to your Department in this question a necessary rectification. When I went to see Mr. Thos. Marr at Minnitonas, before engaging his services at the school, I asked him which wages he would consent to work for, and he said: 75 cents per hour, as he had been assured by Geo. Renef, his member, that such was the rate of pay accepted by the Indian Department. I stated that I could not consent to give these high wages in the present crisis, but that I would willingly make the vouchers for 50 cents per hour.

Mr. Marr has given regularly a big sum of work, either personally or in the conduct of the school pupils, whom he had to assist him constantly, and I would consider it quite unfair, after I had deducted already 33% from his wages that he should lose again 10%.

I trust, therefore, that, owing to this explanation, you will kindly see that the Department sends to Mr. Thos. Marr, of Minnitonas, Man., the sum of $35.05, which is due to him in justice.

Sincerely yours,

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill.

Rev. Father Plourde and the Principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School have requested, during the past two years, that a grant be provided to erect a house for the school engineer. The house used by the hired help at this school was destroyed by fire in 1930. They have asked that the materials only be supplied and state they will contribute all labour in the erection of the building without cost to the Department. Geo. W. Russenholt General Hdwe. - 1,361.50.

We have no funds specially provided in our Estimates for the current fiscal year, but it has been pointed out by Father Plourde that, as only a very small amount of the vote provided towards the erection of the Qu'Appelle School is being utilized this year, the amount required to cover the cost of the materials for the erection of the house for the engineer at the Pine Creek School could be taken from this amount. Approximately $1,500 would be required to purchase the materials, lumber, hardware, etc., delivered on the ground.

As the Church authorities have been making rather urgent requests for the erection of this building during the past two years, and will provide all labour themselves, I would beg to request your favourable consideration to authorizing the expenditure required in the purchase of the materials - the same to be taken from the amount which was provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

Reverend Father,

In my letters of March 19th, 1930, June 9th, 1930 & April 7th 1931, I was mentioning to the Department of Indian Affairs that unless a house was erected for our engineer by the Department, he would finally leave. We have not been able to obtain from the Department any help for this expenditure, although we have asked for it year after year, and our general man & engineer is to leave us this spring.

Since the 25th of February, 1930, date at which the engineer's house was destroyed by a chimney fire, our engineer has been living with his father-in-law. The house has cost $200.00; it consists of one main room with a loft and is warm. Our engineer, as he has to go away, would sell this house for the sum of $120.00 only. I would respectfully urge that you would kindly ask the Department to buy this house for the price mentioned, and if the Department could add the sum of $500.00 during the year for a necessary addition and improvements, the question of a house for our engineer would be solved.

Our engineer would like to have the sum of $130.00 as soon as possible in order to make payments for the new site he is to acquire in a town away from here. As you know, his name is Origène Bourbonnière.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
O.M.I.,

Ottawa, February 16, 1934.

Sir:

For some time past, the church authorities have been urging on the Department the necessity for providing a house for the engineer at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. The engineer's house was destroyed by fire on February 25, 1930.

The Rev. Principal states that he can purchase a house for approximately $130 and have same moved to the school. With additional repairs, he states that the house could be made very suitable for a residence for the engineer of the school. The total cost of purchasing the house and the repairs required are estimated at $750.

Funds are available for this purpose in the current year's Appropriation. It is presumed that you are aware of the necessity for this building, but, before giving definite authority to proceed, the Department would appreciate having an immediate reply, as any work done will have to be authorized in the immediate future, in order that the accounts may reach the Department before the end of March.

Your obedient servant,

I would suggest that I believe there should be better light in the dormitories. The windows give some light but they are small and of such a construction that the beneficial rays of the sun do not reach the sleeping room as I believe they should. One other factor of health has come to my notice and I would suggest that as the Indian child has the obstacle of tuberculosis to fight and no matter how well we may check these cases coming into our schools, we will have the cases that will not do so well and for these cases a sun balcony or solarium is one way .. that might help such cases. These items are of some expense but as conditions improve I believe and monies become easier to get that some consideration could be given to the ... correction of the dormitories and in providing a small solarium for the children, especially the ones that show poor health progress at school. At present we have no sun room. I humbly submit these suggestions, hoping as circumstances improve that we will have your further consideration in respect to any correction you may deem necessary.

Dear Sir:

Re Automatic Plant Batteries.

Our Lister Automatic Electric Plant has worked very satisfactorily since March, 1930. I had thought of waiting to put on the Estimates 1934-1935 the item of the renewal of our Batteries. But after keeping up for the last 4½ years, they are failing and giving away, and I am obliged to ask for the help of the Department sooner than I expected.

The Exide Batteries of Canada Ltd., Winnipeg, charged the sum of $256.85 for putting the Batteries in order when they were bought by the Department from the Seminary of Lebret. It would be rather hard for a Company to tell exactly beforehand the total cost of renewing batteries, without seeing them. I believe, however, that the cost should be likely similar. To avoid any fear of high cost to the Department, I would be willing to pay any expenditure in excess of $250.00; I would also take care of all the transportation charges.

The time of vacation, the summer, is the propitious period when batteries are needed at their minimum, and when they can be most easily replaced. Later it is very hard to do without them. I hope, therefore, that you would kindly obtain for us the necessary authorization to proceed with the renewal of our batteries immediately.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
O.M.I.,

Sir:

For some time past, the Department has been allowing grant at the rate of $40 a month towards the salary of the night watchman at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School. The amount available for this purpose is limited, and, as a number of Indian residential schools, which formerly did not receive any grant, are now requesting similar consideration, the Department finds it necessary to only allow grant towards the night watchman's services for a period of seven months.

Consequently, in the case of the night watchman at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, the allowance will only be made until April 30, 1935. MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Replying to your memorandum of the 11th inst., with reference to the request of Reverend Father Plourde, that a truck be purchased for use at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, Camperville, Man., I would say that there is no doubt this equipment would be of service in the transporting of freight from the nearest railway station to the school. It has not been the general policy to supply trucks to residential schools, except in one or two cases. We could, no doubt, provide the funds, approximately $1,100.00, from the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year.

I should be pleased to have your instructions as to whether the truck should be purchased. If approved, would you please state the names of firms in Winnipeg from whom prices should be obtained.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, December 12, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, together with accounts covering the cost of work and materials purchased by the Principal.

In this connection I would point out that all the expenditure was incurred by the Principal without reference to the Department and without obtaining the necessary authority. It is extremely difficult to find funds for expenditures of this nature. However, it has been decided to reimburse the Principal to the extent of $408.81, in payment of accounts as follows:

Joseph Wery & Sons - $134.60
Western Paint Co., Limited - 101.56

Eaton Company, reimbursement is not being made covering the cost of blankets, ticking, covering for comforters and mattresses or for the bedroom furnishings, as this equipment is considered to be replacements and should be paid for by the school authorities, from their per capita allowance or other receipts. Please advise the Principal accordingly.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, February 4, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department has received a request from the Principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, forwarded by Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., Winnipeg, that the hot water tank be repaired; that a new gasoline engine be supplied, to operate the dough mixer and churn, to replace the present engine, which is worn out, and also that vents be installed in the roof, at each end of the school, to ventilate the water closets in both the boys' and girls' departments. It is stated that the Principal secured an estimate of the cost of repairs to the hot water tank, amounting to $74.00, and for the supplying of the gas engine, $80.00.

The Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of a gas engine, of the type that would be satisfactory to operate the dough mixer and churn. The cost should not exceed the estimate submitted by the Principal, viz.: $80. You should arrange, also, to have the necessary repairs made to the hot water tank. The cost of this work should not exceed the estimate submitted by the Principal, viz.: $74.

Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the above authorized repairs and purchase. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. I would request that you take up the matter with the Principal, ascertain what he requires and have the repairs made to the tank and the engine supplied, at an early date.

The Department will have no funds to install vents in the roof in order to ventilate the toilets of the school. Rev. Father Plourde is being informed that the repairs to the hot water tank and the purchase of the engine have been placed in your hands.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear sir,

I beg to inform you that we have no more root house for our vegetables. The one we had, 35 years old, fell in entirely a few days ago and cannot be repaired. The roof and the lining put inside, being entirely rotten, gave in under the weight. And the hay barn, built on the top of the root cellar, being also 35 years old, is to collapse also before long.

Our root cellar is a square of 50 feet, - 8 feet high. To build another one 14,000 ft. of lumber will be required. So material and labor will cost about $900.00.

Be kind enough, dear sir, to grant us the necessary money to build a new root cellar, and oblige me.

Yours very truly,

During my recent visit to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, the Sister Superior requested that certain changes be made in the layout of the rooms used as infirmary's for the pupils. At present two rooms are available for hospitals with a toilet adjoining. There is no room for the nurse. I beg to enclose a sketch of the rooms with the suggested improvements. At present the girls infirmary and the nurses room are the only rooms used, and the suggestion is that the toilet room be partitioned for an infirmary for the boys, leaving a room for the nurse between the two infirmaries. The toilet would have to be changed, a door cut in the wall, and the washbasin placed on the proposed partition. The bath would also have to be moved closer to the proposed door. I was not able to get prices for this work as the school is more or less isolated, and it would be expensive to get a plumber in to make an estimate of the cost. The placing of the partition and cutting a place through the wall would not be expensive, but a first class carpenter would have to be employed.

I beg to suggest that this improvement be allowed to stand for the present. In the course of time repairs will have to be made to the plumbing system and then would be the time to have an estimate made on this improvement.

I believe the suggestion is excellent, and is approved by the Doctor. The pencil marks shows the position of the door and partition.

Will you please advise in this matter.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 3, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to the request of the Sister Superior of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, to have certain changes made in the layout of the rooms used as infirmaries for the pupils and enclosing a sketch of the proposed changes.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will have no funds during the balance of the present fiscal year to carry out the work as requested by the Reverend Sister. These improvements will have to stand for the present.

I would suggest that you bring this matter to the attention of the Department after our appropriation for the coming fiscal year is available, next spring. Consideration will then be given. At the same time, you should state in detail what work is required to the plumbing system and give an estimate of the cost.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.

Honorable T.A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Honourable Sir:

When I was appointed last June, Principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, I found the large school barn in such a precarious condition that I had to repair it immediately. The roof threatened to collapse as some of the pillars and rafters were out of line and the floors had sagged more than 6 inches in some places. As the older School Boys had to perform their daily chores under these dangerous conditions, I really felt that I had to proceed immediately with the necessary repairs rather than have my boys run the risk daily of being killed or injured for life. So I had these repairs made without waiting for authority from the Department.

I have since been told that this method can hardly be approved and that I should not have acted without the consent of the agent. However, when it is realized that Pine Creek is 40 miles from the nearest railroad station and that our agent lives at Portage-la-Prairie, my manner of acting becomes, I believe, much less objectionable.

The total amount of the enclosed invoices for these repairs is not very large and I hope that you will be kind enough to authorize payment in full.

May I be permitted, before closing this letter, to call your attention to the rather sad state of the Indians and Half-breeds of this district in the matter of hospital accommodation? It is true that there is a small hospital at Winnipegosis, but it is 40 miles distant from Pine Creek and in spring, fall and winter, it is difficult of access. It is only in the summer time, when the roads are dry, that we can easily take sick people to this hospital. If your department would approve the building of a small addition to our school, similar to the one that was erected this past summer at Fort Alexander, it would help very materially in solving the problems of this poor district as far as sickness is concerned. After all, you are

(our representatives)
our representative in Ottawa and as such, are expected to do for your constituents at least as much as you have done for others.

I submit this case to you in all confidence and hope that you will give it your early and favorable attention.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) L. Gauthier, O.M.I.,

Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Father Gauthier:

In reply to that part of your letter of December 2 which asks that a hospital addition be built at the Pine Creek Indian Residential School I must say first of all that it would be difficult, if not almost impossible, to include funds for this purpose in the estimates for the fiscal year which will begin next spring. I really thought when assistance was given in the establishment of a hospital at Winnipegosisis that the Federal Government's contribution for hospital purposes in that district might be regarded as complete but I do not want to close the matter with what might be regarded as a refusal to consider your project. As you have in mind the welfare both of Indian wards of the Federal Government and of half-breeds I think your position would be stronger if you could secure some assurance that the Provincial Government would participate. With this assurance it might be possible to consider, or at least discuss, the matter next summer in anticipation of the estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40.

My dear Father Gauthier,

Pressure of other matters has prevented me from acknowledging before this your letter of the 2nd instant, in which, among other things, you refer to the repairs you made to the large school barn. I have discussed the matter with the Director of the Branch; this expenditure has now been approved and payment will be made in due course.

I have noted your remarks regarding the question of hospital accommodation at Camerville. The Branch hoped when assistance was given to the hospital at Winnipegosis it would, to a large extent, relieve the situation in that district. However, in view of the representations you have made, I am asking that the whole situation should be reviewed.

Wishing you the Compliments of the Season,

I am

Yours sincerely,

Reverend L. Gauthier, D.D., F.S.,
Principal,
Pine Creek Indian Residential School,
CAMERVILLE, Manitoba.
